extras.origin: Named after Elbridge Gerry (1812) whose redistricting map looked like a salamander.

content.phrase: Get a foot in the door

meanings.english: To have a chance to do something; to enter a business/organization at a low level.

content.usage: An internship is a great way to get a foot in the door at a big company.

extras.mnemonic: Salesmen used to put a foot in the door so the owner couldn't close it, gaining a chance to talk.

meanings.english: Earn a merit point for doing well.

content.usage: You get a gold star for finishing your homework early.

extras.mnemonic: Teachers put gold star stickers on good papers.

meanings.english: Start doing something immediately and with energy.

content.usage: We have a lot to do, so let's get cracking.

extras.mnemonic: Cracking a whip to start a horse moving fast.

meanings.english: Start talking about the most important facts or details.
meanings.hindi: असली मुद्दे पर आना / बुनियादी बातों पर चर्चा करना।

content.usage: Stop making small talk and let's get down to brass tacks.

extras.mnemonic: Brass tacks were used to measure fabric exactly on a counter; getting to them meant getting to the real measure.
extras.origin: Likely from the drapery trade or upholstery.

meanings.english: To be in a difficult situation or trouble.

content.usage: He got into a soup by borrowing money from a loan shark.

extras.mnemonic: Being stuck in thick, hot soup would be messy and uncomfortable.

content.phrase: Get on like a house on fire

meanings.english: To become friends quickly and have a great relationship.
meanings.hindi: बहुत जल्दी घुल-मिल जाना / गहरी दोस्ती होना।

content.usage: They met yesterday and are getting on like a house on fire.

extras.mnemonic: A fire spreads through a house very rapidly and intensely.

meanings.english: To annoy or irritate someone.
meanings.hindi: नाक में दम करना / परेशान करना।

content.usage: That loud music is getting on my nerves.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting a raw nerve causes pain/irritation.

content.phrase: Get one's ducks in a row

meanings.english: Have everything properly organized.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तैयारी करना / सब कुछ व्यवस्थित रखना।

content.usage: We need to get our ducks in a row before the presentation.

extras.mnemonic: Mother ducks lead their ducklings in a straight, organized line.
extras.origin: Nature observation or possibly carnival shooting games.

meanings.english: To irritate or annoy someone.

content.usage: It really gets my goat when people cut in line.

extras.mnemonic: Goats were put with racehorses to calm them; stealing the goat would upset the horse.

meanings.english: Start doing something; set a process in motion.

content.usage: I'll make the first donation to get the ball rolling.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, the game starts when the ball moves.

meanings.english: Learn how to use or do something.
meanings.hindi: किसी काम को करने का तरीका सीख लेना।

content.usage: It took me a while to get the hang of this new software.

extras.mnemonic: Learning how a tool 'hangs' or balances in your hand.

meanings.english: To be dismissed from a job.

content.usage: He got the sack for stealing office supplies.

extras.mnemonic: Workmen used to carry tools in a sack; getting the sack back meant you were leaving.

meanings.english: To get an advantage or control.

content.usage: Our team got the upper hand in the second half of the game.

extras.mnemonic: In a hand-over-hand stick game, the person whose hand is on top wins.
extras.origin: From an old game of determining order.

meanings.english: Hear about something secret; suspect something.

content.usage: If the media gets wind of this scandal, we are finished.

extras.mnemonic: Animals smell (get wind of) hunters before seeing them.

meanings.english: Organise your life or work in a better way.
meanings.hindi: अपना काम ठीक से करना / सुधर जाना।

content.usage: You need to get your act together if you want to pass this course.

extras.mnemonic: An actor must know lines and moves (the act) to perform well.

meanings.english: Annoying people by interfering or being present.

content.usage: The children were running around getting in everyone's hair.

extras.mnemonic: Like lice or tangles in hair that are irritating and hard to remove.

meanings.english: To stay away from someone or something; to avoid.

content.usage: I give that angry dog a wide berth whenever I walk past.

extras.mnemonic: Berth is the space a ship needs to turn/anchor; give a dangerous ship lots of space.

content.phrase: Give a piece of one's mind

meanings.english: Reprimand; scold angrily.

content.usage: He was so rude that I had to give him a piece of my mind.

extras.mnemonic: Sharing a part of your thoughts (which are angry ones).

meanings.english: Compromise; mutual adjustment.

content.usage: Marriage requires a lot of give and take.

extras.mnemonic: You give something and take something; balance.

meanings.english: To accept defeat; yield.

content.usage: After hours of arguing, he finally gave in.

extras.mnemonic: Giving your weapon 'in' to the enemy.

meanings.english: Try something.

content.usage: I've never played golf, but I'll give it a shot.

extras.mnemonic: Taking a 'shot' at a target.

meanings.english: Try out something; attempt.

content.usage: This game looks hard, but let's give it a whirl.

extras.mnemonic: Spinning (whirling) a wheel to see what happens.

meanings.english: Pretend to be better than one is; behave arrogantly.

content.usage: Since her promotion, she has started giving herself airs.

extras.mnemonic: Putting on 'airs' means acting lofty/high.

meanings.english: Deliberately ignore someone; treat unfriendliness.

content.usage: I thought we were friends, but she gave me the cold shoulder at the party.

extras.mnemonic: Serving a guest a 'cold shoulder' of mutton instead of a hot meal was a sign to leave.

meanings.english: Call someone on the telephone.

content.usage: I'll give you a ring when I arrive.

extras.mnemonic: Old phones had bells that rang.

meanings.english: Die; stop working (for machines).

content.usage: My old car finally gave up the ghost yesterday.

extras.mnemonic: The 'ghost' is the spirit/soul; giving it up means dying.

meanings.english: Collapse; yield; allow someone to pass.
meanings.hindi: टूट जाना / रास्ता देना / हार मान लेना।

content.usage: The bridge gave way under the heavy load.

extras.mnemonic: Giving the 'way' (path) to something else; or structure letting go.

meanings.english: Express anger or frustration.

content.usage: He gnashed his teeth in fury when he lost the game.

extras.mnemonic: Grinding teeth together is a physical sign of suppressed rage.
extras.origin: Biblical phrase 'weeping and gnashing of teeth'.

meanings.english: Something in conflict with one's values or natural instincts.
meanings.hindi: स्वभाव के विरुद्ध / ज़मीर के ख़िलाफ़।

content.usage: Lying to my parents goes against the grain for me.

extras.mnemonic: Rubbing wood against the direction of fibers (grain) is rough and difficult.

meanings.english: Go bankrupt; fail completely.
meanings.hindi: दिवालिया हो जाना / बंद हो जाना।

content.usage: During the pandemic, many small businesses went belly up.

extras.mnemonic: Dead fish float with their belly up.

meanings.english: Become crazy or extremely excited/angry.
meanings.hindi: पागल हो जाना / आपे से बाहर हो जाना।

content.usage: The crowd went bonkers when the team scored.

extras.mnemonic: Bonk means hit on the head; getting hit makes you crazy.

meanings.english: Fail completely and spectacularly.

content.usage: His presentation went down in flames because he wasn't prepared.

extras.mnemonic: A plane shot down crashes in flames; total destruction.

meanings.english: Divide the cost; pay for oneself.

content.usage: Let's go Dutch on dinner tonight.

extras.mnemonic: Attributed to Dutch customs of thriftiness/sharing.
extras.origin: Anglo-Dutch wars propaganda (stereotyping Dutch as stingy).

meanings.english: Use only a small amount of; treat gently.
meanings.hindi: हल्का हाथ रखना / कम इस्तेमाल करना।

content.usage: Go easy on the salt; the soup is already salty.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'easy' or gentle with the supply.

meanings.english: To be sold very cheaply.

content.usage: The antique table went for a song at the auction.

extras.mnemonic: Singing a song is easy/cheap payment compared to money.
extras.origin: Refers to street performers singing for pennies or cheap sheet music.

meanings.english: Attack the weakest or most vital part aggressively.
meanings.hindi: कमजोर नस पर वार करना / जानलेवा हमला करना।

content.usage: In the debate, he went for the jugular by attacking his opponent's record.

extras.mnemonic: Jugular vein is vital; cutting it kills instantly.

meanings.english: An ambitious person who actively chases success.

content.usage: We need a go-getter to lead the sales team.

extras.mnemonic: Someone who 'goes' and 'gets' what they want.

meanings.english: Become out of control; stop working correctly.

content.usage: The computer system went haywire after the power surge.

extras.mnemonic: Wire used to bundle hay is springy and tangles easily; chaotic.

meanings.english: Explode (bomb); Ring (alarm); Stop liking (food/person).

content.usage: The bomb went off in the market.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb with multiple meanings.

meanings.english: Review; examine carefully.

content.usage: Let's go over the details once more.

extras.mnemonic: Going 'over' the surface of something to check it.

meanings.english: Prices rising very high; or becoming very angry.

content.usage: Petrol prices have gone through the roof recently.

extras.mnemonic: Breaking through the roof means going higher than the house limits.

meanings.english: A cemetery (usually beside a church).

content.usage: He was buried in God's acre behind the old chapel.

extras.mnemonic: An acre of land dedicated to God (for the dead).

meanings.english: A born fool.

content.usage: Don't listen to him; he acts like God's ape.

extras.mnemonic: An ape mimics humans but isn't one; a natural fool.

meanings.english: Begin or carry on with an activity.

content.usage: How should we go about solving this problem?

extras.mnemonic: Going around doing things.

meanings.english: Begin to work seriously.

content.usage: Enough chatting, let's get down to business.

extras.mnemonic: Getting serious about the task.

meanings.english: Have a friendly relationship.

content.usage: Despite the age gap, they get on well.

extras.mnemonic: Getting 'on' the same path together.

meanings.english: Smile broadly because of happiness.

content.usage: He was grinning from ear to ear after winning the lottery.

extras.mnemonic: A smile so wide it seems to touch both ears.

meanings.english: Should; ought to (strong advice/warning).

content.usage: You had better leave now before the rain starts.

extras.mnemonic: It would be 'better' if you 'had' done this.

content.phrase: Not have a leg to stand on

meanings.english: To have no evidence or logic to support one's argument.

content.usage: Without a receipt, you don't have a leg to stand on for a refund.

extras.mnemonic: A stool needs legs to stand; an argument needs proof.

meanings.english: Strong and healthy (especially of old people).

content.usage: At 80, he is still hale and hearty.

extras.mnemonic: Hale = Whole/Healthy.

meanings.english: Together; closely connected.

content.usage: Poverty and crime often go hand in hand.

extras.mnemonic: Holding hands signifies unity.

meanings.english: Treat someone with extreme care or delicacy.
meanings.hindi: सावधानी और नरमी से पेश आना।

content.usage: He is very sensitive, so handle him with kid gloves.

extras.mnemonic: Kid gloves are made of soft baby goat leather; used for delicate tasks.

meanings.english: Easily and without doubt.

content.usage: This is hands down the best burger I've ever eaten.

extras.mnemonic: A jockey winning a race easily can put his hands down and relax.

meanings.english: Listen very carefully.

content.usage: The audience hung on his every word.

extras.mnemonic: Metaphorically holding onto words so none drop.

meanings.english: To be ashamed.

content.usage: He hung his head in shame after admitting the lie.

extras.mnemonic: Looking down avoids eye contact, a sign of shame.

meanings.english: Take retirement (especially from sports).
meanings.hindi: संन्यास लेना / खेल से रिटायर होना।

content.usage: The cricketer decided to hang up his boots after the World Cup.

extras.mnemonic: Hanging boots on the wall because you won't wear them anymore.

meanings.english: In a dangerous or precarious situation.
meanings.hindi: नाजुक हालत में होना / डोर पर लटकना।

content.usage: After the scandal, his career is hanging by a thread.

extras.mnemonic: Sword of Damocles hung by a single horsehair; very fragile.

meanings.english: To be deaf or partially deaf.

content.usage: Speak louder, he is hard of hearing.

extras.mnemonic: Hearing is hard (difficult) for them.

content.phrase: Have a bee in one's bonnet

meanings.english: To be obsessed with an idea; to keep talking about something repeatedly.
meanings.hindi: धुन सवार होना / किसी बात को बार-बार दोहराना।

content.usage: She has a bee in her bonnet about healthy eating.

extras.mnemonic: A bee trapped under a hat (bonnet) buzzes constantly and annoys the wearer; like an obsessive thought.

meanings.english: To scold or criticize severely.

content.usage: The manager hauled him over the coals for missing the deadline.

extras.mnemonic: Dragging someone over hot coals was a medieval torture/ordeal.

meanings.english: To have a grievance or issue to discuss/argue.

content.usage: I have a bone to pick with you regarding the broken window.

extras.mnemonic: A dog picking a bone implies focus and chewing; focusing on a problem.

content.phrase: Have a chip on one's shoulder

meanings.english: To hold a grudge; be angry about perceived unfair treatment.
meanings.hindi: मन में कड़वाहट रखना / गुस्से में रहना।

content.usage: He has had a chip on his shoulder ever since he didn't get the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Boys used to place a wood chip on their shoulder and dare others to knock it off to start a fight.

content.phrase: Have a foot in the grave

meanings.english: To be near death or very old.

content.usage: He looks so sick, as if he has one foot in the grave.

extras.mnemonic: Standing at the edge of a grave, almost falling in.

meanings.english: To be good at gardening.

content.usage: Look at her beautiful garden; she really has green fingers.

extras.mnemonic: Handling plants makes fingers green from chlorophyll.
extras.origin: UK: Green fingers / US: Green thumb.

meanings.english: To be victorious at the end of an argument or competition.

content.usage: They mocked him, but he had the last laugh when he won the award.

extras.mnemonic: Laughing at the end is the only laugh that matters.

meanings.english: To have more important work to do.

content.usage: I can't stay for tea; I have other fish to fry.

extras.mnemonic: Cooking (frying) fish is a task; having other fish means other tasks.

meanings.english: To want something very much.
meanings.hindi: दिल से चाहना / धुन सवार होना।

content.usage: She has her heart set on going to Paris.

extras.mnemonic: Setting your heart (desire) firmly on an object.

meanings.english: To be fond of someone or something; feel affection.

content.usage: Grandpa has a soft spot for his youngest grandchild.

extras.mnemonic: A 'soft' spot is tender and yielding to pressure (affection).

content.phrase: He who laughs last laughs loudest

meanings.english: The person who wins in the long term is the real winner.
meanings.hindi: अंत भला तो सब भला / असली जीत आखिरी जीत होती है।

content.usage: They are winning now, but remember, he who laughs last laughs loudest.

extras.mnemonic: Proverb indicating patience leads to final victory.

meanings.english: Daydreaming; cut off from reality.
meanings.hindi: हवाई किले बनाना / वास्तविकता से दूर।

content.usage: He's not paying attention; he has his head in the clouds.

extras.mnemonic: Clouds are high up; being there means you aren't grounded.

meanings.english: Deeply in love.

content.usage: They met last week and are already head over heels in love.

extras.mnemonic: Tumbling (somersault) completely out of control.

meanings.english: People will be punished or fired.

content.usage: If the project fails, heads will roll in the management.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to beheading (execution); losing one's head/job.

meanings.english: Feel sorrow or sympathy for.

content.usage: My heart goes out to the families of the victims.

extras.mnemonic: Sending your heart (love/care) to someone.

meanings.english: Delay; or to rob.

content.usage: Sorry I'm late; I was held up in traffic.

extras.mnemonic: Holding something up stops it from moving forward.

meanings.english: In disorderly haste; confused and hurried.

content.usage: People ran helter-skelter when the alarm rang.

extras.mnemonic: Rhyming phrase implying chaos.

meanings.english: Everywhere.

content.usage: I searched high and low for my keys.

extras.mnemonic: Searching high places and low places covering all space.

meanings.english: Arrogant; behaving as if superior.

content.usage: She acts all high and mighty now that she's rich.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'high' above others leads to arrogance.
extras.origin: Originally referred to rulers, now negative.

meanings.english: Overbearing; using power without considering others.

content.usage: The employees resented the manager's high-handed decisions.

extras.mnemonic: A hand raised high to strike or command forcefully.

meanings.english: To live luxuriously.

content.usage: After winning the lottery, they are living high on the hog.

extras.mnemonic: The best meat (loin/ham) comes from the upper part (high) of the pig (hog).

meanings.english: Became very frightened.
meanings.hindi: खून जम जाना (डर से) / भयभीत होना।

content.usage: His blood ran cold when he saw the ghost.

extras.mnemonic: Fear causes blood vessels to constrict, making you feel cold.

meanings.english: Reach a situation that leads to nothing further.
meanings.hindi: ऐसी स्थिति में आना जहाँ से आगे का रास्ता बंद हो।

content.usage: Our investigation has hit a dead end.

extras.mnemonic: A street closed at one end.

meanings.english: Explode in anger.
meanings.hindi: आग बबूला होना / गुस्से से उछल पड़ना।

content.usage: Dad hit the ceiling when I crashed the car.

extras.mnemonic: Jumping up in anger so high you hit the roof.

content.phrase: Hit the nail on the head

meanings.english: Say or do something exactly right.

content.usage: You hit the nail on the head with your analysis.

extras.mnemonic: Hammering a nail perfectly requires hitting the head exactly.

meanings.english: No real choice at all; take it or leave it.
meanings.hindi: कोई विकल्प न होना (सिर्फ एक ही विकल्प)।

content.usage: It's Hobson's choice; either we accept the pay cut or we get fired.

extras.mnemonic: Thomas Hobson (stable owner) offered customers the horse nearest the door or none at all.

meanings.english: Meaningless talk designed to trick; nonsense.

content.usage: I don't believe in that astrological hocus pocus.

extras.mnemonic: Magic spell words used by magicians to distract.
extras.origin: Imitation of Latin mass or juggler's phrase.

meanings.english: Endure a difficult situation; refuse to yield.

content.usage: The troops held out against the enemy for weeks.

extras.mnemonic: Holding your position outward against pressure.

meanings.english: To be proud; to have self-respect.

content.usage: After your honest work, you can hold up your head anywhere.

extras.mnemonic: Shame makes you lower your head; pride makes you hold it up.

meanings.english: To be valid or sound (usually an argument).

content.usage: His excuse doesn't hold water.

extras.mnemonic: A bucket with holes cannot hold water; a flawed argument cannot hold truth.

meanings.english: Nurture hope even when the situation looks impossible.

content.usage: They hoped against hope that the rescuers would find survivors.

extras.mnemonic: Hoping even when 'hope' (logic) says otherwise.

meanings.english: Behave in a silly and noisy way.

content.usage: Stop horsing around and do your homework.

extras.mnemonic: Young horses (colts) play roughly.

meanings.english: Common sense; practical wisdom.

content.usage: He may not be educated, but he has a lot of horse sense.

extras.mnemonic: Horses are smart, practical animals.

meanings.english: Different people are suited for different jobs.
meanings.hindi: जैसा काम वैसा आदमी / हर काम के लिए उपयुक्त व्यक्ति।

content.usage: I wouldn't hire an artist to do accounting; it's horses for courses.

extras.mnemonic: Certain horses run better on certain racecourses (wet/dry/flat).

meanings.english: Noisy expression of public anger or alarm.

content.usage: There was a great hue and cry about the new taxes.

extras.mnemonic: Hue (shout) and Cry (call); a public outcry to catch a criminal.
extras.origin: Old English legal term for pursuing criminals.

meanings.english: To save; to use economically.
meanings.hindi: किफायत से खर्च करना / बचत करना।

content.usage: We must husband our resources to survive the winter.

extras.mnemonic: Husband originally meant 'house-bound' or manager of the house; implying careful management.

meanings.english: Something that makes a good situation even better.

content.usage: The promotion was great, but the bonus was the icing on the cake.

extras.mnemonic: Cake is good; sweet icing on top makes it perfect.

content.phrase: If it's not one thing, it's another

meanings.english: When things keep going wrong one after another.

content.usage: First the car broke, now the roof leaks. If it's not one thing, it's another.

extras.mnemonic: A series of unfortunate events.

meanings.english: Uncomfortable; worried.

content.usage: He felt ill at ease in the fancy restaurant.

extras.mnemonic: Not at ease = ill (badly) at ease.

meanings.english: Well informed; involved in current affairs or events.
meanings.hindi: ताज़ा जानकारी रखना / सक्रिय रूप से शामिल।

content.usage: After being away for a month, it took a while to get back in the swim.

extras.mnemonic: Fish in the swim (current) move with the flow; those out of it are left behind.
extras.origin: Fishing metaphor regarding schools of fish.

meanings.english: In a confused, nervous, or excited state.

content.usage: The bride was in a flutter just before the ceremony.

extras.mnemonic: Like a bird fluttering its wings nervously.

meanings.english: In a difficult situation or trouble.

content.usage: I forgot my wallet at home and now I am in a pickle.

extras.mnemonic: Being preserved in vinegar (pickle) is an uncomfortable state for a vegetable.

meanings.english: In debt or financial difficulty.

content.usage: Bad investments left him in Queer Street.

extras.mnemonic: Queer meant 'strange' or 'bad'; being on this street meant trouble.
extras.origin: Allegedly refers to Carey Street in London, where the bankruptcy court was located.

meanings.english: In a difficult situation that is hard to escape.

content.usage: His resignation put the team in a tight corner.

extras.mnemonic: Being cornered with no room to move.

meanings.english: Not suitable; offensive or vulgar.

content.usage: His jokes about the funeral were in bad taste.

extras.mnemonic: Just as bad food tastes awful, bad comments feel awful to hear.

meanings.english: In an alliance or conspiracy (usually negative).

content.usage: The police suspected the judge was in cahoots with the mob.

extras.mnemonic: Cahoots sounds like 'co-hoots' (owls hooting together).
extras.origin: French 'cahute' (small cabin); sleeping in the same cabin implied partnership.

meanings.english: Cruelly and deliberately; without emotion.

content.usage: The crime was committed in cold blood.

extras.mnemonic: Hot blood implies passion/anger; cold blood implies calculation and lack of feeling.
extras.origin: Old medical belief that blood temperature determined emotion.

meanings.english: In great difficulty or trouble.

content.usage: He found himself in deep water after lying to the IRS.

extras.mnemonic: If you can't swim, deep water is dangerous.

meanings.english: In a very bad or difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: नाजुक हालात में / घोर संकट में।

content.usage: The company is in dire straits and might close soon.

extras.mnemonic: A strait is a narrow water passage; difficult to navigate. Dire means terrible.

meanings.english: In trouble or disfavor.

content.usage: I'm in Dutch with the boss for missing the meeting.

extras.mnemonic: Historical English rivalry with the Dutch led to negative phrases (Dutch courage, Dutch treat).

meanings.english: At the height of activity.

content.usage: The party was in full swing when we arrived.

extras.mnemonic: A swing moving at its highest arc is in 'full swing'.

meanings.english: In the routine of daily work; on duty.

content.usage: He died in harness, working until his last day.

extras.mnemonic: A horse in harness is ready to pull the cart/work.

meanings.english: Full of hope and enthusiasm; happy.

content.usage: The team was in high spirits after the victory.

extras.mnemonic: Spirits = Mood; High = Good.

meanings.english: In place of; instead of.
meanings.hindi: के बदले में / के स्थान पर।

content.usage: He gave a donation in lieu of a gift.

extras.mnemonic: Lieu sounds like 'loo' (place); in the place of.

meanings.english: Rising in power or influence.
meanings.hindi: उन्नति पर / प्रभुत्व बढ़ रहा हो।

content.usage: Her political career is currently in the ascendant.

extras.mnemonic: Ascend means to go up.
extras.origin: Astrology (a sign rising over the horizon).

meanings.english: Cheerless; depressed; dejected.

content.usage: He's been in the blues since he failed the exam.

extras.mnemonic: The 'Blues' musical genre expresses sadness.

meanings.english: In an early stage.

content.usage: The plan is still in the egg and needs development.

extras.mnemonic: Before a bird is born, it is in the egg.

content.phrase: In the eye of a storm

meanings.english: Be in the middle of a difficult situation or controversy.

content.usage: The minister found himself in the eye of a storm over the corruption scandal.

extras.mnemonic: The eye is the center of a hurricane.

meanings.english: In favor with someone.
meanings.hindi: किसी की नजरों में अच्छा होना।

content.usage: I cleaned the car to get in my dad's good books.

extras.mnemonic: If you are in the 'good' record book, you are safe.

meanings.english: Eventually; ultimately.

content.usage: It seems hard now, but it will be beneficial in the long run.

extras.mnemonic: Not in a short sprint, but a long run.

meanings.english: Informed regularly.
meanings.hindi: जानकारी में होना / लूप में रहना।

content.usage: Keep me in the loop regarding the project updates.

extras.mnemonic: Being inside the circle (loop) of information.

meanings.english: Just in time; at the last possible moment.

content.usage: The ambulance arrived in the nick of time.

extras.mnemonic: A 'nick' was a notch on a stick used to keep time/score; precise point.

meanings.english: Likely to appear or happen soon.

content.usage: A new trade deal is in the offing.

extras.mnemonic: Offing = the part of the sea visible from shore; if a ship is in the offing, it's coming soon.

meanings.english: In good health.

content.usage: She has recovered and is now in the pink of health.

extras.mnemonic: Pink cheeks often indicate good health (blood flow).
extras.origin: Shakespeare (Romeo and Juliet) - 'the pink of courtesy' (meaning the peak/best).

meanings.english: Contesting for a position; having a good chance to win.

content.usage: He is still in the running for the manager's post.

extras.mnemonic: Running in a race.

meanings.english: In direct opposition to; despite difficulty.
meanings.hindi: के विरोध में / विषम परिस्थितियों में।

content.usage: They succeeded in the teeth of fierce opposition.

extras.mnemonic: Walking straight into the biting teeth of a strong wind.

meanings.english: Popular; in fashion.

content.usage: Bell-bottom pants are back in vogue.

extras.mnemonic: Vogue magazine is about fashion.

meanings.english: Strictly; rigorously.
meanings.hindi: सख्ती से / लोहे के हाथों से।

content.usage: He ruled the country with an iron fist.

extras.mnemonic: Iron is hard; a fist implies force.

meanings.english: Something which is implied to be obvious.
meanings.hindi: यह कहने की जरूरत नहीं है (स्पष्ट है)।

content.usage: It goes without saying that you will be paid for your work.

extras.mnemonic: So true it doesn't need words.
extras.origin: Translation of French 'cela va sans dire'.

meanings.english: Secluded place; state of being detached from everyday reality.

content.usage: Academics in their ivory towers often don't understand real-world problems.

extras.mnemonic: Ivory is expensive and white (pure); high tower is isolated.

meanings.english: Prejudiced view; cynical.

content.usage: He looks at all politicians with a jaundiced eye.

extras.mnemonic: Jaundice makes eyes yellow, so you see everything tinted yellow (distorted).

meanings.english: To cause someone to remember something.

content.usage: Show him the photo to jog his memory.

extras.mnemonic: A gentle shake (jog) to wake up the memory.

meanings.english: Acted hastily; start before the proper time.
meanings.hindi: जल्दबाजी करना / समय से पहले शुरू करना।

content.usage: They jumped the gun by announcing the winner before counting all votes.

extras.mnemonic: Starting the race before the starting gun fires.

meanings.english: Scolding or interrupting angrily.

content.usage: I only asked a question; no need to jump down my throat.

extras.mnemonic: Attacking someone verbally so aggressively it's like jumping into them.

meanings.english: To remain calm, rational, and sensible.

content.usage: In a crisis, it is important to keep a level head.

extras.mnemonic: Level = balanced; not tilted by panic.

meanings.english: Avoid attracting attention.
meanings.hindi: सुर्खियों से दूर रहना / छिपकर रहना।

content.usage: The celebrity tried to keep a low profile while on vacation.

extras.mnemonic: Keeping your head down (low) so you aren't seen.

meanings.english: Keep oneself updated.

content.usage: He reads the newspaper to keep abreast of current affairs.

extras.mnemonic: Abreast means side-by-side; staying alongside the news, not falling behind.

meanings.english: Welcome all visitors.

content.usage: They keep an open house on Sundays for friends and family.

extras.mnemonic: The door is always open.

meanings.english: To control something; prevent from growing too big.

content.usage: You need to keep your spending in check.

extras.mnemonic: In Chess, putting the king in 'check' restricts his movement.

meanings.english: Give them all the information; keep informed.
meanings.hindi: खबर देते रहना / जानकारी साझा करना।

content.usage: Please keep me in the loop regarding the negotiations.

extras.mnemonic: Being part of the communication circle (loop).

meanings.english: To keep something secret.
meanings.hindi: गुप्त रखना / किसी को न बताना।

content.usage: I'll tell you the news, but you must keep it under your hat.

extras.mnemonic: Hiding a secret thought right under your hat (in your head).

meanings.english: To pretend to be happier or richer so as to conceal the real situation.

content.usage: Even though they were bankrupt, they tried to keep up appearances.

extras.mnemonic: Maintaing the external look (appearance) despite internal rot.

meanings.english: Remain cheerful in difficult circumstances.

content.usage: Keep your chin up; things will get better soon.

extras.mnemonic: When you are sad, you look down; looking up (chin up) implies hope.

meanings.english: To be very confident and proud.
meanings.hindi: गर्व से सिर ऊंचा रखना / आत्मविश्वास बनाए रखना।

content.usage: You did your best, so keep your head up.

extras.mnemonic: Opposite of hanging your head in shame.

meanings.english: To stay calm despite great difficulties.
meanings.hindi: होश में रहना / धैर्य बनाए रखना।

content.usage: She kept her head during the fire and guided everyone to safety.

extras.mnemonic: Don't 'lose' your head (panic).

meanings.english: Remain cool; do not get angry.

content.usage: Keep your shirt on! I'll be ready in a minute.

extras.mnemonic: People used to take off their shirts to fight; keeping it on means no fighting.

meanings.english: Calm down.

content.usage: Keep your wig on, there's no need to shout.

extras.mnemonic: If you get too excited, your wig might fall off.

meanings.english: Create a fuss; start a noisy argument.

content.usage: He kicked up a row when he was overcharged.

extras.mnemonic: Row (rhymes with cow) means a noisy argument.

meanings.english: Wasting time while waiting for something.

content.usage: I was left kicking my heels in the lobby for an hour.

extras.mnemonic: Sitting and tapping (kicking) heels out of boredom.

meanings.english: Diagonally opposite each other.

content.usage: The gas station is kitty corner to the bank.

extras.mnemonic: Corruption of 'cater-corner' (four-cornered).

content.phrase: Know like the back of one's hand

meanings.english: To have detailed knowledge of something.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह से जानना / रग-रग से वाकिफ होना।

content.usage: He knows this city like the back of his hand.

extras.mnemonic: You see the back of your hand every day.

meanings.english: To know everything about something.

content.usage: She knows the software inside out.

extras.mnemonic: Knowing both the outside and inside means knowing it completely.

meanings.english: A grave setback; bad treatment when you expected help.

content.usage: Being fired after 20 years was a real kick in the teeth.

extras.mnemonic: Getting kicked in the mouth is painful and humiliating.

meanings.english: Surrendered.

content.usage: The rebels laid down their arms and surrendered.

extras.mnemonic: Putting weapons (arms) on the ground.

meanings.english: Accept eagerly.
meanings.hindi: चाव से स्वीकार करना / आनंद लेना।

content.usage: He lapped up the compliments.

extras.mnemonic: Like a cat drinking milk quickly and happily.

meanings.english: To become firmly attached; to understand.

content.usage: He latched on to the idea immediately.

extras.mnemonic: A latch holds a door shut tightly.

meanings.english: Too delayed to be of no use.

content.usage: It is too late in the day to start studying now.

extras.mnemonic: Sun is setting; day is over.

meanings.english: Laugh loudly.

content.usage: He told a joke and we all laughed like a drain.

extras.mnemonic: The gurgling sound of water going down a drain sounds like a coarse laugh.

meanings.english: To earn great Prestige; distinctions.

content.usage: He won laurels for his scientific discoveries.

extras.mnemonic: Laurel wreaths were worn by victors in ancient Greece.

meanings.english: An exaggeration; flattery.

content.usage: He was really laying it on thick about how great I looked.

extras.mnemonic: Like applying too much paint or makeup.

meanings.english: Dismissal from job.

content.usage: The factory is laying off 100 workers.

extras.mnemonic: To stop employing; lay aside.

meanings.english: To dominate or control someone completely.
meanings.hindi: नाक में नकेल डालना / मनचाहा काम करवाना।

content.usage: He lets his wife lead him by the nose.

extras.mnemonic: Animals (bears/bulls) were led by a ring in their nose.

meanings.english: Ready and efficient; having no excess fat/waste.

content.usage: The company downsized to become lean and mean.

extras.mnemonic: Lean (no fat) + Mean (ready to fight/compete).

meanings.english: To memorize something.

content.usage: You must learn the poem by heart.

extras.mnemonic: Ancient belief that the heart was the center of intelligence/memory.

meanings.english: Learn to do a particular job.

content.usage: It will take a few weeks to learn the ropes of the new job.

extras.mnemonic: Sailors had to learn which rope raised which sail.

meanings.english: Try every possible course of action.
meanings.hindi: कोई कसर न छोड़ना / हर संभव प्रयास करना।

content.usage: Police left no stone unturned in the search for the child.

extras.mnemonic: Looking under every stone to find something hiding.
extras.origin: Greek Oracle of Delphi (advice to find a treasure).

meanings.english: Leave someone in a helpless or difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: मझधार में छोड़ना / मुसीबत में साथ छोड़ना।

content.usage: He resigned suddenly, leaving the team in the lurch.

extras.mnemonic: Lurch was a losing position in a card game; leaving someone there meant they lost.

meanings.english: To be ignored or excluded.

content.usage: During the merger, many employees felt left out in the cold.

extras.mnemonic: Not allowed inside the warm house.

meanings.english: Forget past offences and conflicts.
meanings.hindi: जो बीत गई सो बात गई / पुरानी बातें भूल जाना।

content.usage: Let's stop arguing and let bygones be bygones.

extras.mnemonic: Bygones = things gone by.

meanings.english: To work off excess energy or anger.

content.usage: He went for a run to let off steam.

extras.mnemonic: Steam engines release steam to prevent explosion.

meanings.english: Do not bring up an old controversy or problem.
meanings.hindi: गड़े मुर्दे न उखाड़ना / मुसीबत को न छेड़ना।

content.usage: Don't ask about his divorce; let sleeping dogs lie.

extras.mnemonic: Waking a sleeping dog might make it bite you.

content.phrase: Let something slip through one's fingers

meanings.english: To waste an opportunity.

content.usage: He let the chance to study abroad slip through his fingers.

extras.mnemonic: Trying to hold water/sand in hand; it slips away.

content.phrase: Let the cat out of the bag

meanings.english: Reveal a secret carelessly or by mistake.
meanings.hindi: राज खोल देना / भेद उजागर करना।

content.usage: We planned a surprise party, but she let the cat out of the bag.

extras.mnemonic: Merchants used to sell piglets in bags; if a cat jumped out, the fraud was revealed.

content.phrase: Let the chips fall where they may

meanings.english: Let something happen without bothering about the consequences.
meanings.hindi: परिणाम की चिंता किए बिना कार्य करना।

content.usage: I will tell the truth and let the chips fall where they may.

extras.mnemonic: A woodcutter chopping a tree doesn't worry where the small chips land.

content.phrase: Let the grass grow under one's feet

meanings.english: To remain idle; to delay action.
meanings.hindi: सुस्ती दिखाना / काम में ढिलाई बरतना।

content.usage: Don't let the grass grow under your feet; apply for the job now.

extras.mnemonic: Standing still so long that grass grows around you.

meanings.english: To take it easy and relax; behave freely.

content.usage: It's the weekend; time to let your hair down.

extras.mnemonic: Women used to pin hair up in public and let it down only in private to relax.

meanings.english: A situation where everyone has a fair and equal chance.

content.usage: The new regulations aim to create a level playing field for small businesses.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, if the field is flat (level), neither team has an advantage.

meanings.english: Try not to be noticed; hide.
meanings.hindi: छिप जाना / नजरों से दूर रहना।

content.usage: After the scandal, he decided to lie low for a while.

extras.mnemonic: Lying flat on the ground to avoid being seen.

content.phrase: Like a dying duck in a thunderstorm

meanings.english: Dejected; sad; depressed.

content.usage: He stood there looking like a dying duck in a thunderstorm.

extras.mnemonic: Ducks like water, but a thunderstorm is too much even for them, looking pitiful.

meanings.english: Extremely difficult (usually getting info/money).

content.usage: Getting him to admit the truth was like pulling teeth.

extras.mnemonic: Extracting a tooth is hard and painful.

content.phrase: Like a shag on a rock

meanings.english: Completely alone; isolated.

content.usage: He was left standing there like a shag on a rock.

extras.mnemonic: A shag (cormorant bird) often sits alone on a rock to dry its wings.

content.phrase: Like talking to a brick wall

meanings.english: Talking to someone who is inattentive or stubborn.
meanings.hindi: भैंस के आगे बीन बजाना / अनसुना करना।

content.usage: Arguing with him is like talking to a brick wall.

extras.mnemonic: A wall doesn't listen or respond.

content.phrase: Like two peas in a pod

meanings.english: Very similar; identical.

content.usage: The twins are like two peas in a pod.

extras.mnemonic: Peas from the same pod look exactly alike.

meanings.english: A dangerous situation.

content.usage: Walking into the boss's office today felt like entering the lion's mouth.

extras.mnemonic: Putting your head in a lion's mouth is deadly.

meanings.english: The greatest and most desirable portion of something.

content.usage: She did the work, but her boss took the lion's share of the credit.

extras.mnemonic: The Lion is the King of Beasts and takes whatever part of the kill he wants.

meanings.english: Gradually.

content.usage: Little by little, he recovered his strength.

extras.mnemonic: Adding small amounts over time.

meanings.english: To have enough money to live and nothing extra.
meanings.hindi: गुजारा करना / रोज कमाना रोज खाना।

content.usage: Since losing his job, he has been living from hand to mouth.

extras.mnemonic: The food goes straight from hand to mouth; no storage.

meanings.english: Words that carry more significance or emotional weight than their literal meaning.

content.usage: Politicians often use loaded words to manipulate voters.

extras.mnemonic: Words loaded with gunpowder (explosive meaning).

meanings.english: Completely; everything.

content.usage: They sold the business lock, stock, and barrel.

extras.mnemonic: The three main parts of a musket gun; buying all three means buying the whole gun.

meanings.english: Think carefully about the consequences before acting.
meanings.hindi: बिना विचारे जो करे सो पाछे पछताय / काम करने से पहले सोचो।

content.usage: Investing is risky, so look before you leap.

extras.mnemonic: Check the landing spot before jumping.

meanings.english: Regard with contempt; feel superior to.
meanings.hindi: नीची नज़र से देखना / तुच्छ समझना।

content.usage: He looks down upon people who don't have a degree.

extras.mnemonic: Looking down from a high position implies superiority.

meanings.english: Investigate.

content.usage: The police promised to look into the matter.

extras.mnemonic: Looking inside something to see the truth.

meanings.english: Be careful; watch out.

content.usage: Look out! There's a car coming.

extras.mnemonic: Look outside for danger.

meanings.english: Pay attention; hurry up; or dress smartly.

content.usage: The bus is leaving, look sharp!

extras.mnemonic: Sharp means alert/keen.

meanings.english: Exploring new and better opportunities.

content.usage: He quit his job to go looking for greener pastures.

extras.mnemonic: Animals always look for fresher, greener grass.

meanings.english: Expecting with pleasure.

content.usage: I am looking forward to meeting you.

extras.mnemonic: Looking ahead with joy.

meanings.english: To increase spending; allow money to be spent.

content.usage: The government needs to loosen the purse strings to boost the economy.

extras.mnemonic: Old purses were bags tied with strings; opening them meant spending.

meanings.english: Become embarrassed; lose respect of others.

content.usage: He was afraid to admit his mistake and lose face.

extras.mnemonic: Face represents reputation/dignity.

meanings.english: To go insane; lose one's mind.

content.usage: Have you lost your marbles? That's a terrible idea!

extras.mnemonic: Marbles were a metaphor for wits/mind.

meanings.english: Lose self-control; panic.

content.usage: He lost his head during the argument and started shouting.

extras.mnemonic: If your head is lost, your brain (control) is gone.

meanings.english: Not being as successful or skilled as previously.
meanings.hindi: पकड़ कमजोर होना / कुशलता खो देना।

content.usage: The famous chef seems to have lost his touch; the food wasn't great.

extras.mnemonic: Losing the sensitive 'touch' required for fine work.

meanings.english: One who talks boastfully or reveals secrets; a noisy person.

content.usage: Don't tell him the secret; he's a loudmouth.

extras.mnemonic: Someone whose mouth is always loud and open.

meanings.english: Eccentric; crazy.

content.usage: He talks to himself all day; he's as mad as a hatter.

extras.mnemonic: Hat makers used mercury, which caused nerve damage and madness.
extras.origin: Mercury poisoning in the hat-making industry (18th/19th century).

meanings.english: Treated it lightly; did not take seriously.

content.usage: He made light of his injury, but it was actually serious.

extras.mnemonic: Treating something heavy (serious) as if it is light (unimportant).

meanings.english: Run away with; escape.

content.usage: The thieves made off with the jewelry.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: First speech.

content.usage: The young MP was nervous about her maiden speech in Parliament.

extras.mnemonic: Maiden implies unmarried/virgin/first time (like maiden voyage).

meanings.english: Go straight towards something.

content.usage: Thirsty and tired, he made a beeline for the water cooler.

extras.mnemonic: Bees fly in a straight line back to the hive with nectar.

meanings.english: Confess without reserve; admit a crime or mistake fully.
meanings.hindi: अपना गुनाह कबूल कर लेना / सच उगल देना।

content.usage: He decided to make a clean breast of his involvement in the fraud.

extras.mnemonic: Breast represents the conscience/heart; cleaning it means clearing guilt.

meanings.english: To reduce an amount of something; make noticeable progress.

content.usage: Paying off this loan will make a dent in my savings.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting a car makes a dent (impact); metaphorically impacting a pile of work/money.

meanings.english: To act in a stupid or embarrassing way.
meanings.hindi: हंसी का पात्र बनना / मूर्खता करना।

content.usage: He made a fool of himself by drinking too much at the party.

extras.mnemonic: Turning yourself into a fool by actions.

meanings.english: To make something seem ridiculous or useless; no serious outcome.

content.usage: The unfair trial made a mockery of justice.

extras.mnemonic: Mocking something reduces its seriousness.

meanings.english: Make a public disturbance or emotional display.

content.usage: Please don't make a scene in the restaurant.

extras.mnemonic: Acting dramatically like in a movie 'scene' but in public.

meanings.english: Cause someone to look foolish.

content.usage: If you assume without asking, you make an ass out of yourself.

extras.mnemonic: Ass (donkey) symbolizes stupidity.

meanings.english: To remove, steal, or kill.

content.usage: The burglar made away with all the cash.

extras.mnemonic: Taking something 'away'.

meanings.english: Pretence; imagine.

content.usage: Children like to make believe that they are superheroes.

extras.mnemonic: Making yourself believe something unreal.

meanings.english: Attain fame and success.

content.usage: He finally made big time in Hollywood.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting the 'big time' (major league level).

meanings.english: To become rich.

content.usage: He made a fortune in the real estate business.

extras.mnemonic: Fortune implies wealth/luck.

meanings.english: Understand or figure out (usually negative: can't make head or tail).

content.usage: I couldn't make head or tail of his messy handwriting.

extras.mnemonic: If you can't tell the head from the tail, you don't know what you are looking at.

meanings.english: Do not have any hesitation; state something clearly and directly.

content.usage: She made no bones about her dislike for the new policy.

extras.mnemonic: If soup has no bones, you can swallow it easily without hesitation.
extras.origin: 15th century: finding bones in soup was an obstacle; making no bones means finding no obstacle.

meanings.english: Unable to progress ahead.
meanings.hindi: प्रगति न कर पाना / आगे न बढ़ पाना।

content.usage: Despite working all night, we made no headway on the project.

extras.mnemonic: Moving the 'head' (front) forward.
extras.origin: Nautical: ship moving forward against wind/current.

meanings.english: To run away with something (stolen).

content.usage: The robber made off with the loot.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: To frighten someone.
meanings.hindi: रोंगटे खड़े कर देना / डरा देना।

content.usage: The spooky story made my flesh creep.

extras.mnemonic: Fear causes 'goosebumps' which feels like skin moving/creeping.

meanings.english: Distinguish oneself; achieve recognition/success.

content.usage: He wants to make his mark in the music industry.

extras.mnemonic: Leaving a permanent mark/signature on the world.

meanings.english: Understand someone or something with difficulty.

content.usage: I can't make out what is written on this faded sign.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: Entirely false and fabricated.

content.usage: The story about the ghost was made out of whole cloth.

extras.mnemonic: A suit made from a whole piece of cloth is new; similarly, a lie made from scratch is pure fabrication.

meanings.english: Create space for someone/something.

content.usage: Can you make room for one more person in the car?

extras.mnemonic: Clearing a space.

meanings.english: Dispose of or finish quickly.

content.usage: The hungry kids made short work of the pizza.

extras.mnemonic: Turning a long job into a short one.

meanings.english: Compensate for a loss or mistake.

content.usage: He worked overtime to make up for the lost days.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: Reconcile; resolve differences.

content.usage: They argued but soon made up with each other.

extras.mnemonic: Making the relationship whole again.

content.phrase: Make hay while the sun shines

meanings.english: Take advantage of a favourable opportunity.
meanings.hindi: बहती गंगा में हाथ धोना / मौके का फायदा उठाना।

content.usage: The market is up, so we should sell now and make hay while the sun shines.

extras.mnemonic: Hay must be dried in the sun; if it rains, it spoils.

content.phrase: Many a slip between the cup and the lip

meanings.english: Bad things may happen before a plan is finished; don't count on it until it's done.
meanings.hindi: काम पूरा होने से पहले कुछ भी हो सकता है।

content.usage: He thinks he has won, but there's many a slip between the cup and the lip.

extras.mnemonic: You might drop the cup before the drink reaches your mouth.

meanings.english: Increase the price.

content.usage: Stores often mark up goods by 50%.

extras.mnemonic: Marking a higher price on the tag.

meanings.english: Not willing to speak frankly or directly; evasive.
meanings.hindi: बात को घुमा-फिरा कर कहने वाला / स्पष्टवादी नहीं।

content.usage: Stop being mealy-mouthed and tell us what you really think.

extras.mnemonic: Having a mouth full of meal (flour) makes speech soft and indistinct.

meanings.english: Reach the required standard; be good enough.

content.usage: The new employee didn't measure up to our expectations.

extras.mnemonic: Measuring someone to see if they fit the standard height/size.

meanings.english: Improve your behavior.

content.usage: If you don't mend your ways, you will be expelled from school.

extras.mnemonic: Repairing (mending) bad habits.

meanings.english: A good reason for doing something that looks crazy.
meanings.hindi: पागलपन में भी कोई योजना होना।

content.usage: His filing system looks chaotic, but there is a method to his madness.

extras.mnemonic: It looks mad, but follows a method.

meanings.english: Weak ideas; insipid; lacking substance.

content.usage: The proposal was a milk and water compromise that pleased no one.

extras.mnemonic: Watered-down milk is tasteless and weak.

meanings.english: To speak vaguely or indirectly to avoid offense (usually used in negative: not to mince matters).

content.usage: He didn't mince matters; he told us we were fired.

extras.mnemonic: Mincing meat cuts it small; mincing words cuts the impact.

meanings.english: Sugar-coating; speaking politely to soften the blow.
meanings.hindi: चिकनी-चुपड़ी बातें करना / बात को हल्का करना।

content.usage: I won't mince words: your performance was terrible.

extras.mnemonic: Making words smaller (minced) so they are easier to swallow.

meanings.english: Dishonest or silly behavior.

content.usage: Stop the monkey business and finish your work.

extras.mnemonic: Monkeys are mischievous.

meanings.english: Very tasty and appetizing.

content.usage: The smell of the cake was mouth watering.

extras.mnemonic: Salivating (water in mouth) when seeing food.

meanings.english: Make every possible effort.

content.usage: I will move heaven and earth to get tickets for the concert.

extras.mnemonic: Moving the whole universe to get what you want.

meanings.english: Unfairly alter the rules or criteria during a process.
meanings.hindi: नियम बदल देना (ताकि सफलता न मिले)।

content.usage: Every time I meet the requirements, they move the goalposts.

extras.mnemonic: Moving the goal further away while the game is being played.

meanings.english: Making a big fuss over a small matter.
meanings.hindi: खोदा पहाड़ निकली चुहिया / छोटी बात का बतंगड़।

content.usage: The scandal turned out to be much ado about nothing.

extras.mnemonic: Ado = fuss/trouble.

meanings.english: A murder committed ruthlessly and without emotion.

content.usage: The innocent civilians were murdered in cold blood.

extras.mnemonic: See 'In cold blood'.

meanings.english: Full of suspense, nervousness, or excitement.

content.usage: It was a nail-biting finish to the cricket match.

extras.mnemonic: People bite nails when nervous.

content.phrase: Nail one's colours to the mast

meanings.english: Make one's opinion or allegiance obvious and refuse to change it.
meanings.hindi: डंके की चोट पर कहना / अपना पक्ष स्पष्ट करना।

content.usage: He nailed his colours to the mast regarding the tax reform.

extras.mnemonic: Ships flew flags (colours) on the mast; nailing them meant they couldn't be lowered (no surrender).

meanings.english: Something hard to categorize; having no definite character.
meanings.hindi: ना इधर का ना उधर का / अजीबोगरीब।

content.usage: This strange vehicle is neither fish nor fowl.

extras.mnemonic: Not food for Fast days (Fish) nor Feast days (Fowl); belongs nowhere.

meanings.english: An imaginary Utopian place.

content.usage: He lives in a never never land, ignoring his debts.

extras.mnemonic: Peter Pan's home where children never grow up.

meanings.english: A newcomer; naive.

content.usage: As the new kid on the block, he had to prove himself.

extras.mnemonic: A new child moving into the neighborhood (block).

meanings.english: A short-lived sensation; something popular for a brief time.
meanings.hindi: चार दिन की चांदनी / क्षणिक आकर्षण।

content.usage: The scandal was just a nine days' wonder and was soon forgotten.

extras.mnemonic: Something wonderful that bores people after just over a week.
extras.origin: Old proverb dating back to Chaucer.

meanings.english: Refusal; no success; not happening.

content.usage: I asked for a raise, but no dice.

extras.mnemonic: In gambling, if the dice don't roll, the game doesn't happen.

meanings.english: Intense dislike; they do not like each other.
meanings.hindi: एक-दूसरे को पसंद न करना / 36 का आंकड़ा।

content.usage: There is no love lost between the two rivals.

extras.mnemonic: If no love is lost, it means there was no love to begin with.
extras.origin: 16th century (originally meant extreme love, meaning reversed over time).

meanings.english: Without conditions or restrictions.

content.usage: The scholarship comes with no strings attached.

extras.mnemonic: Like a puppet without strings; free from control.

meanings.english: Remain silent about a secret.
meanings.hindi: चुप रहना / भनक न लगने देना।

content.usage: Promise me you will not breathe a word of this to anyone.

extras.mnemonic: Not even using breath to whisper.

content.phrase: Not fit to hold a candle

meanings.english: Inferior; not as good as someone else.
meanings.hindi: तुलना के लायक न होना / बहुत कमतर होना।

content.usage: As a writer, he is not fit to hold a candle to Shakespeare.

extras.mnemonic: An apprentice held the candle for the master to work; being unfit even for that menial task implies inferiority.

meanings.english: Cannot be believed; unreasonable or flawed argument.
meanings.hindi: तर्कसंगत न होना / झूठ साबित होना।

content.usage: His alibi did not hold water under police questioning.

extras.mnemonic: A leaky bucket doesn't hold water; a leaky argument fails.

meanings.english: State one's opinion clearly and directly.

content.usage: The boss did not mince words about the team's failure.

extras.mnemonic: Opposite of mincing (cutting small); keeping words whole and direct.

meanings.english: To have different opinions; disagree.

content.usage: My father and I do not see eye to eye on politics.

extras.mnemonic: Looking at the same level implies agreement; not doing so implies difference.

content.phrase: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth

meanings.english: Do not find fault with a gift received.
meanings.hindi: दान की बछिया के दांत नहीं गिने जाते।

content.usage: The car is old, but it was free, so don't look a gift horse in the mouth.

extras.mnemonic: You check a horse's age by its teeth; checking a free horse is rude.

meanings.english: To speak frankly and directly.

content.usage: Not to mince matters, your work is unacceptable.

extras.mnemonic: Refusing to soften the blow.

meanings.english: Absolutely not; no chance.
meanings.hindi: बिल्कुल नहीं / सवाल ही नहीं उठता।

content.usage: I asked to borrow his car, but he said, 'Nothing doing'.

extras.mnemonic: Nothing is happening (doing).

meanings.english: Occasionally; from time to time.

content.usage: I see him now and again at the supermarket.

extras.mnemonic: Between now and the next time.

meanings.english: Useless; unsuccessful.

content.usage: All our efforts were of no avail.

extras.mnemonic: Avail means benefit/value; having none.

meanings.english: Of the best quality.

content.usage: He is a diamond of the first water.

extras.mnemonic: In gemology, 'water' refers to the clarity of a diamond; first water is the clearest.

meanings.english: Old-fashioned in thought; traditional.

content.usage: My grandfather is a gentleman of the old school.

extras.mnemonic: Belonging to the old way of teaching/thinking.

meanings.english: Feeling slightly ill; or rude/indecent (joke).

content.usage: You look a bit off colour today.

extras.mnemonic: When sick, your face loses natural color (pale).

meanings.english: Speak without preparation; extempore.

content.usage: He gave a brilliant speech off the cuff.

extras.mnemonic: Speakers sometimes wrote notes on their shirt cuffs for quick reference.

meanings.english: No longer in difficulty or trouble.

content.usage: The police found the real thief, so I am off the hook.

extras.mnemonic: A fish that gets off the hook escapes being caught.

meanings.english: Flattery; smooth talk.

content.usage: Beware of his oily tongue; he is trying to trick you.

extras.mnemonic: Oil makes things smooth; a smooth talker.

meanings.english: Experienced person.

content.usage: He is an old hand at fixing computers.

extras.mnemonic: Someone who has kept their hand in the trade for a long time.

meanings.english: Wise beyond one's age.

content.usage: He manages the business like an old head on young shoulders.

extras.mnemonic: Having the brain of an old (wise) person on a young body.

content.phrase: On a wing and a prayer

meanings.english: With only the slightest chance of success.
meanings.hindi: भगवान भरोसे / बहुत कम उम्मीद के साथ।

content.usage: The damaged plane landed on a wing and a prayer.

extras.mnemonic: A pilot landing a damaged plane relying on one wing and praying.

meanings.english: Because of.

content.usage: The game was cancelled on account of rain.

extras.mnemonic: Accounting for the reason.

meanings.english: Everywhere; on all sides.

content.usage: There was rejoicing on all hands.

extras.mnemonic: Hands pointing/coming from every direction.

meanings.english: Occasionally; intermittently.

content.usage: It has been raining on and off all day.

extras.mnemonic: Switching between on and off states.

meanings.english: Nervous and unable to relax.

content.usage: He was on edge waiting for the exam results.

extras.mnemonic: Sitting on the edge of the seat in suspense.

meanings.english: Friendly relationship.

content.usage: I am on good terms with my neighbors.

extras.mnemonic: Terms of agreement are good.

meanings.english: Careful; vigilant.

content.usage: You must be on your guard against pickpockets.

extras.mnemonic: Acting like a guard.

meanings.english: Near to death or exhaustion; about to fail.

content.usage: My old laptop is on its last legs.

extras.mnemonic: Legs are too tired to support the body anymore.

meanings.english: On foot.

content.usage: We missed the bus, so we had to go on shank's mare.

extras.mnemonic: Shanks are your legs; using them like a horse (mare).

meanings.english: In suspense and anxiety.

content.usage: The audience was on tenterhooks waiting for the winner.

extras.mnemonic: Tenters were frames to stretch cloth; tenterhooks held the cloth tight. Being on them implies tension.

meanings.english: Very close to a critical point (often disaster or success).

content.usage: The two countries are on the brink of war.

extras.mnemonic: Brink is the edge of a cliff.

meanings.english: Likely to happen.

content.usage: A promotion is on the cards for him.

extras.mnemonic: Written on the Tarot cards (destiny).

meanings.english: On credit.

content.usage: He bought the drinks on the cuff.

extras.mnemonic: Bartenders used to write debts on their stiff shirt cuffs.

meanings.english: At a fast pace; immediately.

content.usage: Get over here on the double!

extras.mnemonic: Double time implies twice the speed.

meanings.english: Judging by how it appears; prima facie.
meanings.hindi: पहली नज़र में / ऊपरी तौर पर।

content.usage: On the face of it, the deal looks good, but read the details.

extras.mnemonic: Looking at the face/surface only.

meanings.english: An event that is likely to happen soon.

content.usage: There is trouble on the horizon for the company.

extras.mnemonic: You can see it coming from the horizon.

meanings.english: In a risky situation (often 'skating on thin ice'); or delayed.

content.usage: His bad behavior puts him on thin ice with the boss.

extras.mnemonic: Ice is slippery and can break; dangerous.

meanings.english: Honest; genuine.

content.usage: Is this offer really on the level?

extras.mnemonic: A level surface is flat and straight, not crooked.

meanings.english: To understand and agree; to have the same knowledge.
meanings.hindi: सहमत होना / एक ही बात सोचना।

content.usage: We need to make sure everyone is on the same page before the meeting.

extras.mnemonic: Reading from the exact same page of a book.

content.phrase: On the spur of the moment

meanings.english: To act suddenly, without planning.

content.usage: We decided to go on a trip on the spur of the moment.

extras.mnemonic: Spurring a horse makes it move instantly.

content.phrase: On the tip of my tongue

meanings.english: About to be said or remembered, but not quite there.
meanings.hindi: जुबान पर होना (पर याद न आना)।

content.usage: The actor's name is on the tip of my tongue.

extras.mnemonic: The word is so close it's almost out of the mouth.

meanings.english: Very close to experiencing something.

content.usage: He was on the verge of tears.

extras.mnemonic: Verge is a border or edge.

meanings.english: Declining; becoming weaker.

content.usage: His popularity is on the wane.

extras.mnemonic: The moon wanes (shrinks) after being full.

content.phrase: On the wrong side of sixty

meanings.english: To be older than sixty.

content.usage: He is on the wrong side of sixty but still very active.

extras.mnemonic: The 'right' side is being younger; 'wrong' is older.

meanings.english: Finally; permanently.

content.usage: Let's settle this argument once and for all.

extras.mnemonic: Do it once, and it counts for all future times.

meanings.english: An unpleasant experience makes one cautious in the future.
meanings.hindi: दूध का जला छाछ भी फूंक-फूंक कर पीता है।

content.usage: I won't lend him money again; once bitten, twice shy.

extras.mnemonic: If a dog bites you once, you are double careful next time.

meanings.english: Always thinking of only one thing.
meanings.hindi: एक ही रट लगाए रहना / संकीर्ण सोच।

content.usage: He has a one-track mind; he only talks about football.

extras.mnemonic: A train on a single track can only go one way.

meanings.english: Having no planned ending; flexible.
meanings.hindi: जिसकी कोई निश्चित सीमा या अंत न हो।

content.usage: It was an open-ended discussion with no fixed agenda.

extras.mnemonic: Like a box with the end open; anything can go in or out.

meanings.english: Totally; completely (often in a bad way).

content.usage: That is an out and out lie.

extras.mnemonic: Inside and out; completely.

meanings.english: Poor; impoverished; wearing worn-out clothes.

content.usage: Since losing his fortune, he has been out at the elbows.

extras.mnemonic: Clothes so old that the elbows have worn through.

meanings.english: Forbidden; prohibited.

content.usage: The staff room is out of bounds for students.

extras.mnemonic: Outside the playing area boundary.

meanings.english: Greatly confused or frightened.

content.usage: The loud noise scared me out of my wits.

extras.mnemonic: Wits = mind/intelligence; driven out of your mind by fear.

meanings.english: A book that is no longer available from the publisher.

content.usage: I wanted to buy that book, but it is out of print.

extras.mnemonic: No longer being printed.

meanings.english: To be unwell; feeling slightly ill or upset.

content.usage: He's been feeling a bit out of sorts lately.

extras.mnemonic: Sorts were typeface letters; running out of sorts meant a printer couldn't work properly.

meanings.english: Completely unexpectedly.

content.usage: She called me out of the blue after five years.

extras.mnemonic: From 'a bolt out of the blue' (lightning from a clear blue sky).

meanings.english: Impossible; not to be considered.
meanings.hindi: असंभव / जिस पर विचार न किया जा सके।

content.usage: Buying a new car is out of the question right now.

extras.mnemonic: Outside the realm of discussion (questioning).

meanings.english: No longer in trouble or danger.

content.usage: The patient is stable but not yet out of the woods.

extras.mnemonic: Woods can be dark and dangerous; getting out implies safety.

meanings.english: Appear suddenly and mysteriously.
meanings.hindi: गायब से प्रकट होना / हवा में से।

content.usage: The magician made a rabbit appear out of thin air.

extras.mnemonic: Air is invisible; appearing from it is magic.

meanings.english: Extraordinary; amazing.

content.usage: The cake she baked was simply out of this world.

extras.mnemonic: So good it doesn't belong on Earth.

meanings.english: To spoil something by trying too hard to improve it; to exaggerate.
meanings.hindi: ज़रूरत से ज़्यादा सुधार कर काम बिगाड़ना।

content.usage: Don't over-egg the pudding; keep the speech simple.

extras.mnemonic: Adding too many eggs ruins the pudding's texture.

meanings.english: Completely; deeply (usually in love or debt).
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह से / सिर से पांव तक।

content.usage: He is over head and ears in debt.

extras.mnemonic: Submerged completely in water.

meanings.english: Opposing something fiercely; completely forbidding it.

content.usage: You'll sell this house over my dead body!

extras.mnemonic: You have to kill me to do it.

meanings.english: To seem less important or impressive.

content.usage: My problems pale into insignificance compared to yours.

extras.mnemonic: Bright colors fade (pale) and become less noticeable.

meanings.english: To dispose of something unwanted by deception; to trick someone into accepting.

content.usage: He tried to palm off his old car as a vintage classic.

extras.mnemonic: Magicians use 'palming' to hide cards; hiding a flaw to pass it on.

meanings.english: To hide problems rather than fixing them.

content.usage: The government's new policy just papers over the cracks in the economy.

extras.mnemonic: Putting wallpaper over a cracked wall hides the damage but doesn't fix the structure.

meanings.english: A prolific source of problems; something that triggers many unforeseen troubles.

content.usage: Investigating that scandal opened a Pandora's box of corruption.

extras.mnemonic: Pandora opened a forbidden jar/box releasing all evils into the world.

meanings.english: An essential or integral part.

content.usage: Stress is part and parcel of this job.

extras.mnemonic: Legal term referring to parts of land/property bound together.

meanings.english: A parting hit; a final hostile remark made while leaving.

content.usage: As he slammed the door, he fired a Parthian shot about my cooking.

extras.mnemonic: The Parthian archers shot arrows backwards while retreating.

meanings.english: Shift responsibility to others.

content.usage: The CEO passed the baton to his son.

extras.mnemonic: Relay race runners pass the baton to the next runner.

meanings.english: Refuse to accept responsibility and blame others.

content.usage: Don't try to pass the buck; it was your mistake.

extras.mnemonic: In poker, a 'buck' (knife) was passed to mark the dealer; passing it meant passing the duty.

meanings.english: Collect money.

content.usage: They passed the hat around to buy a gift for the teacher.

extras.mnemonic: Street performers pass a hat to the crowd for coins.

meanings.english: Approval or praise for doing something good.

content.usage: He deserves a pat on the back for his hard work.

extras.mnemonic: Physical gesture of praise.

meanings.english: Pay promptly; pay immediately in cash.

content.usage: He is a reliable customer; he always pays on the nail.

extras.mnemonic: The 'nail' was a small table in stock exchanges where money was counted.
extras.origin: Medieval market custom (The Nails in Bristol/Limerick).

meanings.english: Pretend to support or agree without taking action.
meanings.hindi: सिर्फ कहने के लिए हां करना / झूठा समर्थन।

content.usage: Politicians often pay lip service to environmental issues but do nothing.

extras.mnemonic: Using lips (speech) but not hands (action).
extras.origin: Biblical reference to honoring with lips but heart is far.

meanings.english: Drive very fast; work as fast as possible.

content.usage: We're late! Put the pedal to the metal.

extras.mnemonic: Pushing the gas pedal all the way down until it hits the metal floor.

meanings.english: Select only the best from choices.
meanings.hindi: चुन-चुन कर लेना / अपनी पसंद का छांटना।

content.usage: You can't just pick and choose the easy tasks.

extras.mnemonic: Being selective.

meanings.english: Analyse critically to find faults.
meanings.hindi: नुक्स निकालना / बाल की खाल निकालना।

content.usage: The critics picked his performance to pieces.

extras.mnemonic: Tearing something apart piece by piece.

meanings.english: Finding fault with.

content.usage: He loves picking holes in my arguments.

extras.mnemonic: Looking for holes (flaws) in a fabric/argument.

meanings.english: Treat someone badly or unfairly; bully.

content.usage: The older kids used to pick on him at school.

extras.mnemonic: Selecting someone repeatedly for bad treatment.

meanings.english: Something good that is unlikely to happen; illusory hope.

content.usage: His plan to become a millionaire overnight is just pie in the sky.

extras.mnemonic: A pie floating in the sky is unreachable and unreal.
extras.origin: From a song 'The Preacher and the Slave' (1911).

meanings.english: From one place to another (often fruitlessly).

content.usage: He was driven from pillar to post looking for a job.

extras.mnemonic: Originally from tennis (hitting ball back and forth); implies helpless movement.

meanings.english: Allowance made to a lady for her personal expenses.

content.usage: She uses her pin money to buy books.

extras.mnemonic: Money used to buy pins (which were once expensive luxuries for women).

meanings.english: An idea or plan that is impossible or unlikely to happen.

content.usage: His plan to colonize Mars next year is a pipe dream.

extras.mnemonic: Dreams experienced while smoking an opium pipe (unreal hallucinations).

meanings.english: Very obvious and easy to understand.

content.usage: It's plain as day that he is lying.

extras.mnemonic: Daylight makes everything visible.

meanings.english: Very easy; smooth progress.

content.usage: Once we got past the city traffic, it was plain sailing.

extras.mnemonic: Sailing on a calm sea without storms.

meanings.english: Spend lavishly; waste money foolishly.
meanings.hindi: पानी की तरह पैसा बहाना / बर्बाद करना।

content.usage: He played ducks and drakes with his inheritance.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing stones to skip on water (game called ducks and drakes); treating money like stones thrown away.

meanings.english: To make excuses or delay to gain time.

content.usage: He kept asking questions just to play for time.

extras.mnemonic: Playing the game slowly to let the clock run out.

meanings.english: To use one's best weapon or resource.

content.usage: He played his ace by revealing the secret document.

extras.mnemonic: Ace is the highest card in the deck.

meanings.english: Stay away from duty or school without permission.

content.usage: The boys decided to play truant and go to the cinema.

extras.mnemonic: Truant refers to a beggar/vagabond; wandering instead of working.

meanings.english: Caused destruction or chaos.

content.usage: The storm played havoc with the flight schedules.

extras.mnemonic: Havoc was a military order to loot/pillage.

meanings.english: Acting to gain approval from the masses; appeasing the public.
meanings.hindi: जनता को रिझाना / सस्ती लोकप्रियता पाना।

content.usage: The politician's speech was just playing to the gallery.

extras.mnemonic: The gallery (cheapest seats) in a theater held the common people; acting to please them.

meanings.english: Bear an insult quietly without reacting.
meanings.hindi: अपमान का घूँट पीना / अपमान सह लेना।

content.usage: He had to pocket the insult to keep his job.

extras.mnemonic: Putting the insult in your pocket (hiding it) instead of fighting back.

meanings.english: Directly; very close; blunt.

content.usage: He refused my request point blank.

extras.mnemonic: Shooting from close range where the bullet travels flat/straight to the white (blank) center.

meanings.english: To interfere in other's affairs.

content.usage: Stop poking your nose into my private life.

extras.mnemonic: Sticking your nose where it doesn't belong.

meanings.english: Go through; examine or read carefully.
meanings.hindi: गहराई से अध्ययन करना / ध्यान मग्न होना।

content.usage: She poured over the documents late into the night.

extras.mnemonic: Not 'pour' (liquid); 'pore' means to look closely.

meanings.english: Dinner where everybody brings something to eat.
meanings.hindi: ऐसी दावत जहाँ सब अपना खाना लाते हैं।

content.usage: We are having a pot luck dinner on Friday.

extras.mnemonic: Taking the 'luck' of what is in the 'pot'; everyone contributes.

meanings.english: Discourage; criticize a plan.
meanings.hindi: उत्साह ठंडा करना / पानी फेर देना।

content.usage: He poured cold water on my idea of a road trip.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing cold water on a fire (enthusiasm) puts it out.

meanings.english: Give a detailed plan or scheme.

content.usage: The agreement provides a blueprint for peace in the region.

extras.mnemonic: Blueprints are technical drawings for buildings.

content.phrase: Pull a rabbit out of the hat

meanings.english: To do something unexpected or solve a problem surprisingly.

content.usage: The team needs to pull a rabbit out of the hat to win this match.

extras.mnemonic: Classic magician trick.

meanings.english: Play a trick; deceive someone.

content.usage: He tried to pull a fast one by selling me a fake watch.

extras.mnemonic: Moving too fast for the victim to see the trick.

meanings.english: Look dejected, depressed, or sad.

content.usage: Why are you pulling a long face on your birthday?

extras.mnemonic: Gravity pulls facial features down when sad.

meanings.english: Speak frankly, directly, and honestly without holding back.
meanings.hindi: कोई रियायत न बरतना / कड़ाई से पेश आना।

content.usage: The review pulled no punches about the movie's flaws.

extras.mnemonic: In boxing, pulling a punch means hitting softly; pulling NO punches means hitting hard.

meanings.english: Make something happen; succeed in a difficult task.

content.usage: I don't know how he pulled off that victory.

extras.mnemonic: Pulling a prize off the shelf?

meanings.english: Use personal influence to get something done.
meanings.hindi: जुगाड़ लगाना / प्रभाव का इस्तेमाल करना।

content.usage: He pulled some strings to get his son a job.

extras.mnemonic: Like a puppeteer controlling a puppet with strings.

meanings.english: Prevent something from happening; stop a project.
meanings.hindi: बंद कर देना / रोक लगा देना।

content.usage: The studio pulled the plug on the movie due to budget issues.

extras.mnemonic: Pulling the plug out of a drain or socket stops the function.

content.phrase: Pull the wool over someone's eyes

meanings.english: Deceive someone by telling lies.

content.usage: Don't try to pull the wool over my eyes; I know the truth.

extras.mnemonic: Woolen wigs were common; pulling the wig over the eyes blinds the person.

meanings.english: Work harmoniously; cooperate.

content.usage: We need to pull together to finish this project on time.

extras.mnemonic: Pulling a heavy load together (like a team of horses).

meanings.english: To put in extra effort; improve performance.

content.usage: You need to pull up your socks if you want to pass the exam.

extras.mnemonic: Getting ready for action (running/fighting) by securing loose clothing.

meanings.english: To calm yourself; recover control of emotions.

content.usage: Stop crying and pull yourself together.

extras.mnemonic: Gathering your scattered emotions back into one piece.

content.phrase: Pull the chestnuts out of the fire

meanings.english: Accomplish a difficult job for someone else, often at personal risk.
meanings.hindi: किसी और के लिए खतरा मोल लेना।

content.usage: He wanted me to pull the chestnuts out of the fire while he stayed safe.

extras.mnemonic: From a fable where a monkey persuades a cat to pull hot chestnuts from a fire, burning the cat's paw.
extras.origin: La Fontaine's Fables (The Monkey and the Cat).

meanings.english: To do something with maximum effort and resources.
meanings.hindi: एड़ी-चोटी का जोर लगाना / कोई कसर न छोड़ना।

content.usage: They pulled out all the stops for the wedding ceremony.

extras.mnemonic: In a pipe organ, pulling out 'stops' allows all pipes to sound, creating maximum volume.

meanings.english: Effectively convey or communicate an idea.

content.usage: He put his ideas across very clearly in the meeting.

extras.mnemonic: Moving an idea 'across' to the other person.
