meanings.english: Execute; implement.

content.usage: It's time to put our plans into action.

extras.mnemonic: Making something active.

meanings.english: Delay; postpone.

content.usage: Don't put off until tomorrow what you can do today.

extras.mnemonic: Moving a task off the current schedule.

content.phrase: Put one's cards on the table

meanings.english: To be honest and open about one's intentions.

content.usage: It's time to put our cards on the table and negotiate honestly.

extras.mnemonic: Showing your hand in a card game; hiding nothing.

meanings.english: Take a firm stand; refuse to yield.
meanings.hindi: सख्ती से मना करना / अड़ जाना।

content.usage: She put her foot down and refused to work on weekends.

extras.mnemonic: Stamping a foot to show authority or firmness.

meanings.english: Save (usually money) for future use.

content.usage: She puts a little money by every month for emergencies.

extras.mnemonic: Putting something to the side (by) for later.

meanings.english: Reason logically; guess the truth from clues.
meanings.hindi: कड़ी से कड़ी जोड़ना / सही अनुमान लगाना।

content.usage: Seeing the muddy shoes, he put two and two together and realized who went out.

extras.mnemonic: Basic math; drawing an obvious conclusion.

meanings.english: Went out of business; stop trading.

content.usage: Many shops had to put up the shutters during the recession.

extras.mnemonic: Shops close by putting up shutters; doing it permanently means closing business.

meanings.english: Try as hard as one can; make a good impression.

content.usage: Put your best foot forward in the interview.

extras.mnemonic: Stepping forward confidently with the 'best' foot.

meanings.english: Work in consultation and cooperatively.

content.usage: If we put our heads together, we can solve this puzzle.

extras.mnemonic: Bringing heads close to whisper/discuss.

content.phrase: Putting the cart before the horse

meanings.english: Doing things in the wrong order.

content.usage: Buying furniture before buying a house is putting the cart before the horse.

extras.mnemonic: The horse pulls the cart; putting the cart in front makes movement impossible.

meanings.english: Rise from extreme poverty to great wealth.
meanings.hindi: फर्श से अर्श तक / गरीबी से अमीरी।

content.usage: His life is a classic rags to riches story.

extras.mnemonic: Rags (poor clothes) to Riches (wealth).

meanings.english: Warn of a dangerous situation.
meanings.hindi: खतरे की घंटी बजाना / सचेत करना।

content.usage: The watchman raised the alarm when he saw the smoke.

extras.mnemonic: Making noise (alarm) to warn others.

meanings.english: To set higher goals or standards.

content.usage: The new smartphone raises the bar for all competitors.

extras.mnemonic: In high jump, raising the crossbar makes the jump harder.

meanings.english: Move in harmony; have a good relationship.
meanings.hindi: तालमेल होना / एक ही ढर्रे पर चलना।

content.usage: The two partners ran in the same groove and built a successful firm.

extras.mnemonic: Wheels or records running smoothly in their grooves.

meanings.english: Meet accidentally.

content.usage: I ran into my old teacher at the mall.

extras.mnemonic: Colliding (running into) someone by chance.

meanings.english: Acted without restraint; grew uncontrollably.

content.usage: Weeds ran riot in the neglected garden.

extras.mnemonic: Riot implies uncontrolled chaotic behavior.

meanings.english: Ordinary workers or members of an organization (not leaders).

content.usage: The rank and file of the party are unhappy with the leadership.

extras.mnemonic: In army formation, soldiers stand in ranks (rows) and files (columns).

meanings.english: An exceptional person or thing.

content.usage: An honest politician is a rare bird these days.

extras.mnemonic: Exotic birds are rare and valuable.

meanings.english: Fierce, competitive struggle for power and money.

content.usage: He quit the corporate rat race to live on a farm.

extras.mnemonic: Rats racing in a maze for cheese; pointless competition.

meanings.english: Understand what is implied but not stated directly.

content.usage: His letter was polite, but reading between the lines, he is angry.

extras.mnemonic: Finding meaning in the white space (lines) between the text.

meanings.english: Suffer negative consequences of one's own actions.

content.usage: They sowed the wind of rebellion and now reap the whirlwind of war.

extras.mnemonic: If you plant wind (trouble), you harvest a tornado (disaster).

meanings.english: Clue intended to distract or mislead.

content.usage: The mysterious phone call was just a red herring in the murder case.

extras.mnemonic: Smoked herring (fish) turns red and smells strong; used to distract hunting dogs from the scent.

meanings.english: Official procedure causing delay; excessive bureaucracy.

content.usage: We had to cut through a lot of red tape to get the permit.

extras.mnemonic: Legal documents used to be tied with red tape; untying them took time.

meanings.english: Wasting time creating something that already exists.
meanings.hindi: व्यर्थ परिश्रम करना (जो पहले से हो चुका है)।

content.usage: Don't reinvent the wheel; just use the existing template.

extras.mnemonic: The wheel is already perfect; inventing it again is useless.

meanings.english: To be satisfied with past achievements and stop trying.
meanings.hindi: पुरानी सफलताओं पर ही निर्भर रहना।

content.usage: You won the championship, but you can't rest on your laurels if you want to win again.

extras.mnemonic: Sleeping on the victory wreath (laurels) instead of competing again.

meanings.english: Show arrogance and conceit; feel superior.

content.usage: Get off your high horse and admit you were wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Tall horses were for nobility/officers; riding one implies looking down on others.

meanings.english: To set money/funds aside for a specific purpose; protect assets.

content.usage: The grant money is ring-fenced for education projects only.

extras.mnemonic: Building a fence in a ring around sheep to keep them safe/separate.

meanings.english: To revive old forgotten quarrels.
meanings.hindi: गड़े मुर्दे उखाड़ना / पुराने झगड़े ताजा करना।

content.usage: There is no point in ripping up old scores now.

extras.mnemonic: Scores refers to debts/records; bringing them back up causes trouble.

meanings.english: To become successful again after a total failure.
meanings.hindi: राख से उठ खड़ा होना / पुनर्जीवित होना।

content.usage: The company rose like a Phoenix from the ashes of bankruptcy.

extras.mnemonic: The mythical Phoenix bird burns and is reborn from its ashes.

meanings.english: Deal with a difficult situation successfully.
meanings.hindi: अवसर के अनुरूप प्रदर्शन करना / चुनौती स्वीकारना।

content.usage: He was nervous, but he rose to the occasion and gave a great speech.

extras.mnemonic: Rising up to meet the challenge.

meanings.english: Wake up very early.
meanings.hindi: मुर्गे की बांघ के साथ उठना / बहुत जल्दी उठना।

content.usage: Farmers usually rise with the lark.

extras.mnemonic: Larks are birds that sing at dawn.

meanings.english: Refusing to speak about something.
meanings.hindi: जुबान बंद रखना / कुछ न बोलना।

content.usage: The police remained tight-lipped about the investigation.

extras.mnemonic: Lips pressed tight together prevent speech.

meanings.english: To reduce or decrease something to a previous level.
meanings.hindi: वापस लेना / पुरानी स्थिति में लाना।

content.usage: The store rolled back prices to attract customers.

extras.mnemonic: Rolling a carpet/wheel back to where it started.

meanings.english: Get ready to do something difficult or hard work.
meanings.hindi: कमर कसना / काम के लिए तैयार होना।

content.usage: It's time to roll up our sleeves and clean this mess.

extras.mnemonic: You roll sleeves up so they don't get dirty while working.

meanings.english: Completely; radically.

content.usage: The organization needs root and branch reform.

extras.mnemonic: Destroying or changing a tree from the roots to the branches (everything).

meanings.english: A positive outlook of life (often ignoring flaws).

content.usage: She sees the world through rose coloured glasses and ignores the dangers.

extras.mnemonic: Looking through pink lenses makes everything look warm and pleasant.

meanings.english: Annoy someone.

content.usage: His arrogant tone really rubs me the wrong way.

extras.mnemonic: Stroking a cat's fur against the grain (the wrong way) annoys it.

meanings.english: Annoy or upset someone.

content.usage: The new rules ruffled a few feathers among the staff.

extras.mnemonic: Birds ruffle (fluff up) their feathers when agitated or fighting.

meanings.english: Dominate; be in charge.

content.usage: In their family, the youngest child seems to rule the roost.

extras.mnemonic: The rooster controls the hen house (roost).

meanings.english: Criticize; or look tired/ill.

content.usage: He is always running down his colleagues.

extras.mnemonic: Running over someone (criticizing) or a battery losing power (tired).

meanings.english: Unexpectedly meet or experience.

content.usage: I ran into an old friend at the mall.

extras.mnemonic: Colliding with someone/something.

meanings.english: Experience difficulty.

content.usage: The project ran into rough weather due to lack of funds.

extras.mnemonic: A ship sailing into a storm.

meanings.english: Do something dangerous or barely legal.
meanings.hindi: खतरा मोल लेना / नियम के विरुद्ध जाना।

content.usage: His tax schemes sail close to the wind.

extras.mnemonic: Sailing too close to the wind direction can stop or capsize the boat.

meanings.english: Adolescence; time of youth and inexperience.
meanings.hindi: जवानी के दिन / अनुभवहीनता का दौर।

content.usage: He looks back on his salad days with nostalgia.

extras.mnemonic: Salad is green; 'green' implies youth and inexperience.

meanings.english: Saved at the last moment.

content.usage: I was about to answer the difficult question when the class ended—saved by the bell.

extras.mnemonic: In boxing, the bell ends the round, saving a losing fighter from being knocked out.

meanings.english: Detected a trick or lie.

content.usage: She saw through his fake apology.

extras.mnemonic: Seeing through a mask or disguise.

meanings.english: As good as or better than all others.

content.usage: For reliability, this car is second to none.

extras.mnemonic: If you are second to nobody, you must be first.

meanings.english: Agree with each other.

content.usage: My father and I see eye to eye on most things.

extras.mnemonic: Looking directly at the same level implies agreement.

meanings.english: Become publicly known; come into existence.

content.usage: His secret manuscript finally saw the light of day.

extras.mnemonic: Coming out of darkness into the light.

meanings.english: To sell quickly.

content.usage: The new video game is selling like hot cakes.

extras.mnemonic: Pancakes (hot cakes) taste best fresh, so they sell fast at fairs.

meanings.english: Terminate his service; dismiss someone roughly.

content.usage: After he stole the money, they sent him packing.

extras.mnemonic: Telling someone to pack their bags and go.

meanings.english: Give a correct account; correct a misunderstanding.

content.usage: I want to set the record straight about my resignation.

extras.mnemonic: Fixing a crooked record or account.

meanings.english: Oppose strongly.

content.usage: The villagers set their face against the new dam project.

extras.mnemonic: Turning your face into a hard expression of refusal.

meanings.english: Forget or get rid of something.

content.usage: He tried to shake off the feeling of sadness.

extras.mnemonic: Physically shaking dust or something unwanted off your body.

meanings.english: Mentally active; intelligent.

content.usage: Despite her age, she is as sharp as a tack.

extras.mnemonic: A tack (pin) has a very sharp point.

meanings.english: Dishonest means; barely legal dealing.

content.usage: The lawyer was known for his sharp practice.

extras.mnemonic: Cutting corners too sharply implies danger/dishonesty.

meanings.english: Trembled with fear.

content.usage: The thought of the exam made him shake in his shoes.

extras.mnemonic: Trembling so much that even the shoes vibrate.

meanings.english: Surrender.
meanings.hindi: हार मान लेना / सफेद झंडा दिखाना।

content.usage: After hours of fighting, they finally showed the white flag.

extras.mnemonic: White flag is the universal symbol for surrender or truce.

meanings.english: A simple and magical solution to a complicated problem.

content.usage: There is no silver bullet to solve the economic crisis.

extras.mnemonic: In folklore, a silver bullet is the only way to kill a werewolf instantly.

meanings.english: Criticize someone especially when you do not have the right to do so.

content.usage: Don't sit in judgement of others until you know their story.

extras.mnemonic: Acting like a judge sitting on the bench.

meanings.english: Not to take any side and remain undecided.

content.usage: You can't sit on the fence forever; choose a team.

extras.mnemonic: Sitting between two fields on the boundary fence.

meanings.english: To own something potentially valuable.

content.usage: With that invention, he is sitting on a gold mine.

extras.mnemonic: Literally possessing a source of gold.

meanings.english: To wait before making a decision.

content.usage: I can't decide now; let me sleep on it.

extras.mnemonic: Let the subconscious mind work on the problem during sleep.

meanings.english: Leave quietly.

content.usage: He slipped off early to avoid the traffic.

extras.mnemonic: Sliding away without friction/noise.

meanings.english: Make people feel less offended; calm someone down.

content.usage: The diplomat tried to smooth ruffled feathers after the incident.

extras.mnemonic: Calming a bird by smoothing its agitated feathers.

meanings.english: Easy and agreeable option.

content.usage: He took the soft option and dropped the difficult class.

extras.mnemonic: Soft implies easy/comfortable.

meanings.english: In great demand.

content.usage: This artist is highly sought after by collectors.

extras.mnemonic: People seek (search for) it.

meanings.english: Waste time doing foolish things (often promiscuity) in youth.
meanings.hindi: जवानी की गलतियाँ करना / मौज-मस्ती करना।

content.usage: He sowed his wild oats in his twenties before settling down.

extras.mnemonic: Wild oats are weeds; planting them is useless foolishness.

meanings.english: Give enough proof; convey a lot without words.

content.usage: Her smile speaks volumes about her happiness.

extras.mnemonic: Provides as much information as volumes of books.

meanings.english: Clean and tidy.

content.usage: Keep your room spick and span.

extras.mnemonic: Spick (nail) and Span (wood chip) refer to a new ship; implies brand new condition.

meanings.english: Reveal a secret unintentionally.

content.usage: Who spilled the beans about the surprise party?

extras.mnemonic: Ancient Greek voting used beans; spilling the jar revealed the vote early.

meanings.english: Expend much effort for little gain.

content.usage: We are just spinning our wheels without a clear plan.

extras.mnemonic: A car stuck in mud spins its wheels but doesn't move.

meanings.english: Spread rapidly.

content.usage: The rumor spread like wildfire.

extras.mnemonic: Fire spreads incredibly fast in dry wild areas.

content.phrase: Square peg in a round hole

meanings.english: A misfit in an environment.

content.usage: He felt like a square peg in a round hole at the art school.

extras.mnemonic: You can't fit a square shape into a round hole.

meanings.english: Indifferent; aloof; unfriendly.

content.usage: She seems stand-offish, but she is actually just shy.

extras.mnemonic: Standing off (away) from people.
extras.origin: Nautical (keeping a ship at a distance).

meanings.english: Refused to yield; maintain position.

content.usage: Despite the criticism, he stood his ground.

extras.mnemonic: Military: holding the position (ground) against attack.

meanings.english: Complete halt.

content.usage: The strike brought the city to a standstill.

extras.mnemonic: Standing completely still.

meanings.english: Unchanged position; existing state of affairs.

content.usage: They wanted to maintain the status quo rather than risk change.

extras.mnemonic: Latin for 'the state in which'.

meanings.english: Take credit for something someone else did; overshadow.
meanings.hindi: श्रेय छीन लेना / किसी का प्रभाव कम कर देना।

content.usage: She stole my thunder by announcing her news right before mine.

extras.mnemonic: Playwright John Dennis invented a thunder machine; rivals stole the idea for Macbeth.

meanings.english: Maintain his own opinion despite opposition.

content.usage: The witness stuck to his guns despite rigorous questioning.

extras.mnemonic: A soldier staying at his cannon (gun) even when under attack.

meanings.english: Cause anger in many people; provoke trouble.
meanings.hindi: आफत मोल लेना / मधुमक्खी के छत्ते में हाथ डालना।

content.usage: His controversial speech stirred the hornet's nest.

extras.mnemonic: Hornets attack aggressively if their nest is disturbed.

meanings.english: Won everybody's praise; attracted the most attention.
meanings.hindi: महफिल लूट लेना / सबसे अच्छा प्रदर्शन करना।

content.usage: The little girl stole the show with her dance.

extras.mnemonic: Taking the attention of the entire show for oneself.

meanings.english: Hear something from someone who has direct, personal knowledge.
meanings.hindi: विश्वसनीय स्रोत से (सीधे उससे जिसे पता हो)।

content.usage: I know it's true because I heard it straight from the horse's mouth.

extras.mnemonic: In horse racing, the best tip comes from the stable/horse itself.

meanings.english: Work very hard; make utmost efforts.
meanings.hindi: एड़ी-चोटी का जोर लगाना / खून-पसीना एक करना।

content.usage: He strained every nerve to finish the marathon.

extras.mnemonic: Using every nerve and muscle in the body.

meanings.english: An indication of what might happen.
meanings.hindi: भविष्य का संकेत / हवा का रुख।

content.usage: The small layoffs were a straw in the wind for the company's closure.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing a light straw shows which way the wind is blowing.

meanings.english: To negotiate a deal.

content.usage: They finally struck a bargain over the price of the house.

extras.mnemonic: Striking hands together to seal a deal.

content.phrase: Strike while the iron is hot

meanings.english: To act at the right time; grab a favorable opportunity promptly.
meanings.hindi: मौके का फायदा उठाना / लोहा गरम है मार दो हथौड़ा।

content.usage: The market is booming, so strike while the iron is hot.

extras.mnemonic: A blacksmith must shape iron when it is red hot.

content.phrase: Struck a chill to the heart

meanings.english: Aroused fear.

content.usage: The eerie scream struck a chill to the heart.

extras.mnemonic: Fear feels cold (chill) in the chest.

meanings.english: Had many professional difficulties.

content.usage: The business struck several bad patches before becoming profitable.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting rough patches on a road.

meanings.english: Look very good on you; fit perfectly.

content.usage: That job suits you to a T.

extras.mnemonic: T-square is a tool for precise drawing; fitting exactly.

meanings.english: Last performance or work of a career.

content.usage: The actor's final movie was his swan song.

extras.mnemonic: Ancient belief that a swan sings a beautiful song just before it dies.

meanings.english: Generalized statement.

content.usage: Don't make sweeping statements about an entire group of people.

extras.mnemonic: Sweeping everything into one pile without sorting.

meanings.english: Kept hidden (mistakes/problems).

content.usage: The corruption charges were swept under the carpet.

extras.mnemonic: A lazy way to clean room is sweeping dirt under the rug.

meanings.english: Conceited; proud.

content.usage: Success has made him swollen headed.

extras.mnemonic: Ego making the head swell up.

meanings.english: Imminent danger; a constant threat.

content.usage: The fear of losing his job hung over him like the sword of Damocles.

extras.mnemonic: Legend of Damocles who sat under a sword hanging by a single horsehair to realize the danger of kingship.

meanings.english: Learnt acting or be strongly influenced by someone.

content.usage: You should take a cue from your hardworking brother.

extras.mnemonic: In theater, a 'cue' tells an actor when to speak/act.

meanings.english: Disapprove of.

content.usage: The teacher takes a dim view of cheating.

extras.mnemonic: Seeing something 'dimly' or darkly implies negativity.

content.phrase: Take a leaf out of someone's book

meanings.english: Imitate someone in a particular way.
meanings.hindi: अनुकरण करना / किसी के नक्शेकदम पर चलना।

content.usage: I need to take a leaf out of your book and start exercising.

extras.mnemonic: Tearing a page (leaf) from someone else's book to use it.

meanings.english: Resemble (a parent or relative).

content.usage: She takes after her grandmother.

extras.mnemonic: Following after someone in lineage.

meanings.english: Astonishing; very beautiful.
meanings.hindi: हैरान कर देना / सांसें थम जाना।

content.usage: The view from the mountain took away my breath.

extras.mnemonic: Gasping in awe.

meanings.english: To object strongly.

content.usage: I take exception to your rude tone.

extras.mnemonic: Making an 'exception' or objection.

meanings.english: Start liking someone.

content.usage: He took a fancy to the stray kitten.

extras.mnemonic: Fancy = liking/desire.

meanings.english: To gain confidence; be encouraged.

content.usage: Take heart, things will improve soon.

extras.mnemonic: Heart symbolizes courage.

meanings.english: Handle calmly; deal with easily.
meanings.hindi: सहजता से लेना / बिना घबराए सामना करना।

content.usage: He took the criticism in his stride.

extras.mnemonic: Continuing to walk (stride) smoothly over an obstacle.

content.phrase: Take one's eye off the ball

meanings.english: To stop paying attention for a moment.

content.usage: If you take your eye off the ball, you might lose the deal.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, you must watch the ball to hit/catch it.

content.phrase: Take the bull by the horns

meanings.english: To handle difficulties in a very direct way.

content.usage: I decided to take the bull by the horns and ask for a promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Controlling a bull is safest by holding its horns.

meanings.english: Receive criticism.

content.usage: The captain had to take the heat for the team's loss.

extras.mnemonic: Heat = Anger/Pressure ('If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen').

meanings.english: Truly believe you.

content.usage: I will take you at your word that you will return the money.

extras.mnemonic: Accepting words as truth.

meanings.english: To run away.

content.usage: The boys took to their heels when the owner appeared.

extras.mnemonic: Showing your heels as you run away.

meanings.english: Occupy space.

content.usage: That sofa takes up too much room in the small apartment.

extras.mnemonic: Room = space.

meanings.english: Prepare to go for a war.

content.usage: The two nations took up the hatchet over the border dispute.

extras.mnemonic: Opposite of 'bury the hatchet' (make peace).

content.phrase: Take with a pinch of salt

meanings.english: Not believe something completely.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह सच न मानना / संदेह के साथ स्वीकारना।

content.usage: Take his advice with a pinch of salt; he is not an expert.

extras.mnemonic: Ancient antidote for poison included a grain of salt; take info cautiously like poison.

meanings.english: To harm someone gradually.

content.usage: The long hours are taking a toll on his health.

extras.mnemonic: Toll is a tax; paying a heavy price over time.

meanings.english: Accept something as it looks without thinking deeply.
meanings.hindi: जैसा है वैसा स्वीकार करना / ऊपरी तौर पर मानना।

content.usage: I took his offer at face value, which was a mistake.

extras.mnemonic: Value printed on the face of a coin.

meanings.english: Discussed.

content.usage: We talked over the problem and found a solution.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: Talking nonsense.
meanings.hindi: बकवास करना / बिना सिर-पैर की बातें करना।

content.usage: He doesn't know the facts; he's just talking through his hat.

extras.mnemonic: Muffled speech through a hat makes no sense.

meanings.english: Boasting; unbelievable stories.

content.usage: Grandpa loves telling tall tales about his youth.

extras.mnemonic: A story so 'tall' (big) it's hard to believe.

meanings.english: Problems at the start of a project.

content.usage: The new system has some teething problems.

extras.mnemonic: Babies suffer pain when growing new teeth (early stage).

meanings.english: To affect adversely.

content.usage: Lack of sleep is beginning to tell upon his face.

extras.mnemonic: The effects 'tell' (reveal) the damage.

meanings.english: Too late to do something.
meanings.hindi: अब पछताए होत क्या जब चिड़िया चुग गई खेत / अवसर निकल जाना।

content.usage: I wanted to apply, but that ship has sailed.

extras.mnemonic: Once the ship leaves the port, you can't get on.

meanings.english: There is nothing more to be said; the end.

content.usage: The engine blew up, and that's all she wrote.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to a 'Dear John' letter ending a relationship during WWII.

content.phrase: The straw that broke the camel's back

meanings.english: The last problem in a series leading to a collapse.

content.usage: His rude remark was the straw that broke the camel's back.

extras.mnemonic: A camel can carry a lot, but one tiny straw too many causes collapse.

meanings.english: The affirmative votes are in majority.

content.usage: The Speaker declared, 'The ayes have it'.

extras.mnemonic: Aye = Yes (in parliament).

meanings.english: A dishonest person.

content.usage: Don't trust him; he's a bad egg.

extras.mnemonic: An egg looks fine outside but can be rotten inside.

meanings.english: The most attractive aspect of something.

content.usage: The beauty of this plan is that it costs nothing.

extras.mnemonic: The best part.

meanings.english: Extraordinary; excellent.

content.usage: She thinks her new dress is the bee's knees.

extras.mnemonic: 1920s nonsense slang for 'the best'.

meanings.english: The main leader of the gang; important person.

content.usage: The police caught the big fish of the smuggling ring.

extras.mnemonic: Big fish in the pond.

meanings.english: Main point; central issue.

content.usage: Money is the crux of the matter.

extras.mnemonic: Crux implies a cross or critical junction.

meanings.english: The decision is already taken and irreversible.
meanings.hindi: फैसला हो चुका है (अब पीछे नहीं हट सकते)।

content.usage: I have resigned; the die is cast.

extras.mnemonic: Once dice are thrown, you can't change the numbers.

content.phrase: The early bird catches the worm

meanings.english: One who arrives first will get the best chance of success.
meanings.hindi: जो पहले आता है वही पाता है।

content.usage: I woke up at 5 AM to study; the early bird catches the worm.

extras.mnemonic: Birds eating worms in the morning.

meanings.english: An obvious issue left unaddressed due to its sensitivity.
meanings.hindi: एक बड़ी समस्या जिसे सब अनदेखा कर रहे हैं।

content.usage: His drinking problem was the elephant in the room.

extras.mnemonic: A huge elephant in a small room that everyone ignores.

meanings.english: Unfair means to achieve something are acceptable if the result is good.
meanings.hindi: लक्ष्य सही हो तो रास्ता मायने नहीं रखता।

content.usage: He cheated to help his friend, believing the end justifies the means.

extras.mnemonic: Result (end) excuses the method (means).

meanings.english: Big international bankers.

content.usage: The currency crisis was blamed on the gnomes of Zurich.

extras.mnemonic: Gnomes guard treasure underground (Swiss bank vaults).
extras.origin: Coined by UK politician George Brown (1964).

content.phrase: The grass is greener on the other side

meanings.english: Other people always seem to be in a better situation.
meanings.hindi: दूर के ढोल सुहावने / दूसरों की थाली में घी ज्यादा लगता है।

content.usage: He wants to change jobs, thinking the grass is greener on the other side.

extras.mnemonic: Cows thinking the neighbor's grass is tastier.

meanings.english: Night shift work (midnight to morning).

content.usage: Working the graveyard shift is exhausting.

extras.mnemonic: Working when it's dead quiet like a graveyard.

meanings.english: Jealousy.

content.usage: He was consumed by the green-eyed monster when he saw her with another man.

extras.mnemonic: Jealousy is often depicted as a monster with green eyes.

meanings.english: No decision has been reached yet; uncertain.

content.usage: The jury is still out on whether the new policy will work.

extras.mnemonic: When the jury is out of the courtroom, they haven't decided the verdict yet.

meanings.english: The final problem in a series that causes a collapse or reaction.

content.usage: Him coming late again was the last straw; I fired him.

extras.mnemonic: Short for 'the straw that broke the camel's back'.

meanings.english: The ordinary person; average citizen.

content.usage: This policy is difficult for the man in the street to understand.

extras.mnemonic: A random person walking on the street.

meanings.english: People with a lot of power and influence.

content.usage: The party was full of the movers and shakers of the tech industry.

extras.mnemonic: People who move things and shake things up (make changes).

meanings.english: The most important or practical details.

content.usage: Let's stop talking theory and get down to the nitty-gritty.

extras.mnemonic: Nits and grits are small particles; getting down to the smallest details.
extras.origin: Possible association with grit (sand) or maize; origin debated.

meanings.english: The evil side of human nature; original sin.

content.usage: He tries to be good, but the Old Adam in him sometimes takes over.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to Adam (first man) and his sin in Eden.

content.phrase: The pot calling the kettle black

meanings.english: Someone criticizing another for a fault they also have.
meanings.hindi: उल्टा चोर कोतवाल को डांटे / खुद में दोष होने पर दूसरों को बोलना।

content.usage: He called me lazy? That's the pot calling the kettle black!

extras.mnemonic: Both pots and kettles turn black over a fire; neither should judge.

meanings.english: Very good, honest, and reliable people.

content.usage: These hardworking farmers are the salt of the earth.

extras.mnemonic: Salt was valuable and essential; calling someone salt means they are essential goodness.

meanings.english: The unpleasant or immoral aspects of life.

content.usage: As a cop, he saw the seamy side of the city every night.

extras.mnemonic: The wrong side of a garment where the rough seams show.

content.phrase: The tail is wagging the dog

meanings.english: The less important part is controlling the whole situation.
meanings.hindi: उल्टी गंगा बहना / छोटा हिस्सा बड़े को नियंत्रित करे।

content.usage: The marketing department is deciding product features; the tail is wagging the dog.

extras.mnemonic: Normally the dog wags the tail; if reversed, it's unnatural control.

content.phrase: The thin end of the wedge

meanings.english: A small change that will lead to bigger, often harmful, changes.

content.usage: This small tax increase is just the thin end of the wedge.

extras.mnemonic: A wedge starts thin but gets thick, splitting wood apart.

meanings.english: A small part of a much larger problem.
meanings.hindi: समस्या का एक छोटा हिस्सा (बहुत कुछ छिपा होना)।

content.usage: The reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg.

extras.mnemonic: Only 10% of an iceberg is visible above water.

meanings.english: Things start to go wrong after a period of success.
meanings.hindi: गाड़ी पटरी से उतर जाना / सब कुछ बिखर जाना।

content.usage: The campaign was going well, but the wheels have come off recently.

extras.mnemonic: If wheels fall off a vehicle, it crashes.

meanings.english: Everything; the entire affair.

content.usage: He explained the whole ball of wax to the new recruits.

extras.mnemonic: Origin unclear; possibly legal terminology involving wax seals or land distribution.

meanings.english: The underlying reasons and details.

content.usage: I don't know the whys and wherefores of their divorce.

extras.mnemonic: Wherefore means 'why' (archaic); reasons and explanations.

meanings.english: You can achieve anything you want or go anywhere.
meanings.hindi: दुनिया आपकी मुट्ठी में है / अपार अवसर।

content.usage: You are young and talented; the world is your oyster.

extras.mnemonic: Finding a pearl in an oyster is a treasure; the world is full of treasures for you.

content.phrase: There is no smoke without fire

meanings.english: Rumours usually have some basis in fact.
meanings.hindi: बिना आग के धुआं नहीं उठता।

content.usage: I don't believe all the gossip, but there is no smoke without fire.

extras.mnemonic: Smoke is proof of a fire somewhere.

meanings.english: Very close friends; intimate.

content.usage: Those two have been thick as thieves since kindergarten.

extras.mnemonic: Thieves must trust each other deeply to keep secrets.

meanings.english: Make fast decisions and adjust quickly to changes.

content.usage: In the interview, I had to think on my feet to answer the tricky questions.

extras.mnemonic: Thinking while standing/moving, not sitting and pondering.

content.phrase: Threw a spanner in the works

meanings.english: To do something to stop a plan; sabotage.
meanings.hindi: रंग में भंग डालना / काम बिगाड़ना।

content.usage: The sudden rain threw a spanner in our picnic plans.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing a metal tool (spanner) into machine gears breaks it.
extras.origin: Industrial metaphor (UK usage; US: monkey wrench).

meanings.english: Issued a challenge.

content.usage: He threw down the gauntlet by challenging the champion to a match.

extras.mnemonic: Knights threw down their heavy glove (gauntlet) to challenge someone to a duel.

meanings.english: Completely; in every aspect.

content.usage: He is a patriot through and through.

extras.mnemonic: Penetrating all the way through.

meanings.english: To behave recklessly; take a risk.
meanings.hindi: खतरा मोल लेना / परवाह न करना।

content.usage: She threw caution to the winds and quit her job to travel.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing your caution away into the wind where it is lost.

meanings.english: To admit defeat or failure.

content.usage: After trying for hours, I finally threw in the towel.

extras.mnemonic: A boxer's trainer throws a towel into the ring to stop the fight.

meanings.english: Reject; abandon.

content.usage: She threw over her old friends for a new crowd.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing something over the side (discarding).

content.phrase: Throw the baby out with the bathwater

meanings.english: To discard something valuable along with something undesirable.
meanings.hindi: बुराई के साथ अच्छाई भी त्याग देना।

content.usage: In cutting costs, don't throw the baby out with the bathwater by firing good staff.

extras.mnemonic: In old times, dirty bathwater was tossed out; one had to be careful not to toss the baby too.

meanings.english: Discourage; criticize.

content.usage: He threw cold water on my plan.

extras.mnemonic: Dousing fire (passion) with cold water.

meanings.english: To give up; resign.
meanings.hindi: हार मान लेना / पत्ते फेंक देना।

content.usage: He realized he couldn't win, so he threw up his cards.

extras.mnemonic: Dropping cards on the table means quitting the game.

meanings.english: Surrender; give up.

content.usage: The enemy threw up the sponge after a week of fighting.

extras.mnemonic: Boxers used sponges to wipe faces; throwing it up meant quitting.

meanings.english: To fulfill all requirements.

content.usage: The new house ticks all the boxes for us.

extras.mnemonic: Checking off items on a checklist.

meanings.english: Very pleased or amused.

content.usage: She was tickled pink by the surprise gift.

extras.mnemonic: Laughing (from tickling) until your face turns pink.

meanings.english: To help someone survive a difficult period (usually financially).

content.usage: This loan will tide us over until next month.

extras.mnemonic: Floating on the tide until you reach safe harbor.

meanings.english: Give temporary help (money/food).
meanings.hindi: थोड़े समय के लिए मदद करना।

content.usage: Here is $50 to tide you over until pay day.

extras.mnemonic: Same as tide over.

meanings.english: Get married.

content.usage: They are going to tie the knot next summer.

extras.mnemonic: Handfasting ceremonies involved tying hands together.
extras.origin: Ancient celtic/Hindu traditions of tying items during wedding.

meanings.english: To cut expenditures; live frugally.
meanings.hindi: खर्च कम करना / पेट काटकर जीना।

content.usage: We have to tighten our belts during the recession.

extras.mnemonic: When you have less food (money), you get thinner and tighten the belt.

meanings.english: For a very long time.
meanings.hindi: लंबे समय तक / अनिश्चित काल तक।

content.usage: You can argue till the cows come home, but I won't change my mind.

extras.mnemonic: Cows graze all day and come home very late.

meanings.english: Often; repeatedly.

content.usage: I have told you time and again to lock the door.

extras.mnemonic: Many times.

meanings.english: To accept a challenge.

content.usage: He accepted the gauntlet and agreed to the debate.

extras.mnemonic: Picking up the glove (gauntlet) thrown by an opponent.

meanings.english: To set high goals.

content.usage: Don't settle for less; aim for the stars.

extras.mnemonic: Looking up to the highest point (stars).

content.phrase: To wash dirty linen in public

meanings.english: To discuss private affairs (usually bad) in public.
meanings.hindi: घर का भेद बाहर कहना / बदनामी करना।

content.usage: They should settle their argument at home instead of washing dirty linen in public.

extras.mnemonic: Showing stained/dirty clothes to everyone outside.

meanings.english: To fish; or to manipulate a situation for gain.

content.usage: She was angling for a compliment.

extras.mnemonic: Using an angle (hook) to catch something.

meanings.english: To become king or queen.

content.usage: Queen Elizabeth ascended the throne in 1952.

extras.mnemonic: Going up (ascend) to sit on the royal chair.

meanings.english: Perplexed; confused; lost.

content.usage: I was all at sea with the new computer system.

extras.mnemonic: A ship out of sight of land without navigation is lost.

meanings.english: To be at ease; comfortable.

content.usage: Make yourself at home.

extras.mnemonic: Feeling as safe and relaxed as in your own home.

meanings.english: To present a counter-argument just for the sake of argument.
meanings.hindi: आलोचक की भूमिका निभाना (बहस के लिए)।

content.usage: I agree with you, but let me play devil's advocate to test the idea.

extras.mnemonic: In the Catholic Church, an official (Devil's Advocate) argued against the canonization of a saint to ensure proof.

meanings.english: To be honest and just.

content.usage: He won the game fair and square.

extras.mnemonic: Square implies straight lines and honesty.

meanings.english: Puzzled; surprised; defeated.

content.usage: I was completely floored by the news.

extras.mnemonic: Knocked down to the floor by shock.

meanings.english: In a difficult situation.

content.usage: The flat tire left us in a fix.

extras.mnemonic: A tight spot.

meanings.english: To be in a confusing situation; dilemma.

content.usage: He is in a quandary about which job offer to accept.

extras.mnemonic: Quandary comes from Latin 'quando' (when); uncertainty.

meanings.english: Too distant; very far ahead (in progress).

content.usage: Their technology is light years away from ours.

extras.mnemonic: Light year is a massive astronomical distance.

meanings.english: Overwhelmed with emotion.
meanings.hindi: आंसू छलक आना / भावुक हो जाना।

content.usage: The sad movie moved her to tears.

extras.mnemonic: Emotion moving you physically to cry.

meanings.english: To have no appetite.

content.usage: The dog is off his food; he might be sick.

extras.mnemonic: Staying away (off) from eating.

meanings.english: Experiencing a sustained period of success.

content.usage: Our team is on a roll, winning five games in a row.

extras.mnemonic: A rolling ball keeps moving easily.

content.phrase: To be on pins and needles

meanings.english: To be in an agitated state of suspense or anxiety.

content.usage: I was on pins and needles waiting for the surgery results.

extras.mnemonic: Sitting on sharp pins causes discomfort and restlessness.
extras.origin: Physical sensation of numbness ('pins and needles').

meanings.english: Shocked; surprised.

content.usage: I was taken aback by his sudden rudeness.

extras.mnemonic: Sails pressed back against the mast by a sudden wind change.

content.phrase: To be thrown in at the deep end

meanings.english: Forced to do a difficult task without preparation.
meanings.hindi: बिना तैयारी के मुश्किल काम में डाल देना।

content.usage: On my first day, I was thrown in at the deep end with a huge project.

extras.mnemonic: Thrown into the deep end of a pool to learn swimming instantly.

meanings.english: Run away in fear; withdraw.

content.usage: Seeing the bear, the campers beat a retreat.

extras.mnemonic: Drums beating the signal to retreat.

meanings.english: Make useless effort.
meanings.hindi: हवा में लाठी चलाना / व्यर्थ प्रयास।

content.usage: Arguing with him is like beating the air.

extras.mnemonic: Punching air hits nothing.

meanings.english: To perform a task within time limit.

content.usage: We drove fast to beat the clock.

extras.mnemonic: Finishing before the clock runs out.

meanings.english: To be acquitted; escape punishment.

content.usage: With a good lawyer, he managed to beat the rap.

extras.mnemonic: Rap implies a criminal charge; beating it means winning against it.

meanings.english: To defy; to ignore orders.

content.usage: The rebels bid defiance to the king's army.

extras.mnemonic: Proclaiming (bidding) refusal to obey.

meanings.english: To be a pioneer; start something new.

content.usage: She blazed a trail for women in science.

extras.mnemonic: Cutting marks (blazes) on trees to mark a new path in the forest.

meanings.english: To be friendly and unfriendly at the same time; inconsistent.
meanings.hindi: कभी नरम कभी गरम / अस्थिर विचार।

content.usage: He keeps blowing hot and cold about the wedding.

extras.mnemonic: Breathing hot to warm hands, blowing cold to cool soup; doing opposites.
extras.origin: Aesop's Fables (The Satyr and the Traveller).

meanings.english: To praise oneself.
meanings.hindi: अपनी तारीफ खुद करना / मियां मिट्ठू बनना।

content.usage: He is always blowing his own horn about his achievements.

extras.mnemonic: Making noise about yourself.

meanings.english: To escape.

content.usage: The tiger broke loose from the cage.

extras.mnemonic: Breaking the chains.

meanings.english: Cry suddenly.

content.usage: She broke into tears when she heard the bad news.

extras.mnemonic: Emotion breaking out as tears.

meanings.english: To win the race by a small margin.

content.usage: The runner breasted the tape just ahead of his rival.

extras.mnemonic: The chest (breast) hits the finish line tape first.

meanings.english: To die.

content.usage: The old man breathed his last surrounded by family.

extras.mnemonic: Taking the last breath of life.

meanings.english: To reveal; discover.

content.usage: The investigation brought new facts to light.

extras.mnemonic: Shining a light on hidden things.

meanings.english: Destroy all possible ways of returning; make a decision irreversible.

content.usage: By insulting his boss, he burned all his bridges.

extras.mnemonic: If you burn the bridge after crossing, you can't go back.

meanings.english: Suffer as a result of one's action.

content.usage: He burned his fingers in the stock market crash.

extras.mnemonic: Touching something hot (risky) hurts you.

content.phrase: To burn the candle at both ends

meanings.english: Keep busy all the time; work very hard without rest.
meanings.hindi: दिन-रात काम करना / अपनी शक्ति का अत्यधिक व्यय करना।

content.usage: He looks exhausted because he's been burning the candle at both ends.

extras.mnemonic: A candle lit at both ends burns out twice as fast.

meanings.english: Work or study late into the night.

content.usage: Students often burn the midnight oil before exams.

extras.mnemonic: Using oil lamps to see at night to work.

content.phrase: To call a spade a spade

meanings.english: To be frank and say truth straightforwardly.

content.usage: I like him because he calls a spade a spade.

extras.mnemonic: Calling a tool by its exact name, not a fancy one.
extras.origin: Ancient Greek (Plutarch translation error from 'trough' to 'spade').

meanings.english: To appeal to someone; to like.

content.usage: The shiny car caught his fancy.

extras.mnemonic: Fancy = desire/liking.

meanings.english: To come to their level; overtake.
meanings.hindi: बराबरी करना / पीछे से आकर पकड़ना।

content.usage: He studied hard to catch up with the rest of the class.

extras.mnemonic: Running to reach the person ahead.

meanings.english: To remove obstacles; prepare for action.

content.usage: We need to clear the decks before starting the new project.

extras.mnemonic: Clearing the ship's deck for battle.

meanings.english: To restrict one's freedom or power.

content.usage: The new regulations clipped the company's wings.

extras.mnemonic: Clipping a bird's wings prevents it from flying.

meanings.english: A very narrow margin; uncertain outcome.

content.usage: The election results are too close to call.

extras.mnemonic: So close that the referee cannot 'call' the winner.

meanings.english: To make an honest disclosure; confess.
meanings.hindi: सच बता देना / गुनाह कबूल करना।

content.usage: You should come clean about where you were last night.

extras.mnemonic: Cleaning yourself of the dirt (guilt).

content.phrase: To come out into the open

meanings.english: To become public or evident.

content.usage: The scandal finally came out into the open.

extras.mnemonic: Leaving a hiding place.

meanings.english: To become conscious again; or to agree.

content.usage: She fainted but came round after a few minutes.

extras.mnemonic: Coming back around to the conscious world.

meanings.english: Boasting; exulting loudly.
meanings.hindi: डींग मारना / खुशी से चिल्लाना (जीत पर)।

content.usage: He crowed over his victory all night.

extras.mnemonic: A rooster crows loudly to announce itself.

meanings.english: To ask for help when you don't need it; raise a false alarm.

content.usage: If you cry wolf too often, no one will believe you when it's real.

extras.mnemonic: The boy who cried wolf story.

meanings.english: To think hard.
meanings.hindi: दिमाग पर जोर डालना / सिर खपाना।

content.usage: I cudgeled my brains to remember his name.

extras.mnemonic: Cudgel is a club; metaphorically hitting the brain to make it work.

content.phrase: To cut a long story short

meanings.english: To tell something briefly.

content.usage: To cut a long story short, we missed the flight.

extras.mnemonic: Removing the long details.

meanings.english: To make a bad impression; appear foolish.
meanings.hindi: बुरा प्रभाव डालना / हंसी का पात्र बनना।

content.usage: He cut a sorry figure when he forgot his speech.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 216.

meanings.english: To argue in support of both sides; have both good and bad effects.
meanings.hindi: दोनों तरफ से बात करना / दुधारी तलवार होना।

content.usage: This law cuts both ways; it helps some but hurts others.

extras.mnemonic: A double-edged sword cuts in both directions.

meanings.english: To gain experience from something.

content.usage: He cut his teeth on local politics before running for Congress.

extras.mnemonic: Babies cut their first teeth; implies early experience.

meanings.english: Interrupt someone.

content.usage: I was speaking, but he cut me short.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 222.

meanings.english: To stop talking nonsense and start working.
meanings.hindi: बकवास बंद करना और काम करना।

content.usage: Let's cut the cackle and get to business.

extras.mnemonic: Cackle is the noise hens make; implies useless noise.

meanings.english: To wash and dry dishes.

content.usage: It's your turn to do the dishes.

extras.mnemonic: Performing the task involving dishes.

meanings.english: To manipulate accounts; falsify.

content.usage: He was caught trying to doctor the accounts.

extras.mnemonic: A doctor treats/changes the state of a patient; here changing numbers.

meanings.english: To exaggerate.

content.usage: He is known to draw the longbow when telling stories.

extras.mnemonic: The longbow was a powerful weapon; stories about using it were often exaggerated.

meanings.english: To accept defeat; yield under pressure; apologize humbly.

content.usage: He had to eat humble pie after his prediction failed.

extras.mnemonic: From 'umbles pie' (pie made of deer innards/offal, eaten by servants); implies low status.

meanings.english: Forced to retract one's own words; admit one was wrong.
meanings.hindi: अपने शब्द वापस लेना / गलती मानना।

content.usage: I told him he would fail, but I had to eat my words when he won.

extras.mnemonic: Swallowing the words back into the mouth.

meanings.english: To come to nothing; without any practical result.
meanings.hindi: कोई परिणाम न निकलना / धुएं में उड़ जाना।

content.usage: All his ambitious plans ended in smoke.

extras.mnemonic: Fire burns out and leaves only smoke (nothing solid).

meanings.english: To try every opportunity/possibility.

content.usage: Police are exploring every avenue to solve the crime.

extras.mnemonic: Walking down every street (avenue) to find the destination.

meanings.english: To feel easy and comfortable.
meanings.hindi: आरामदायक महसूस करना / घर जैसा लगना।

content.usage: She made us feel at home immediately.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 845.

meanings.english: To make every possible effort; fight ferociously.
meanings.hindi: जी-जान से लड़ना / एड़ी-चोटी का जोर लगाना।

content.usage: She fought tooth and nail to keep custody of her children.

extras.mnemonic: Using both teeth (biting) and nails (scratching) in a fight.
extras.origin: Ancient description of wild animal fighting.

meanings.english: To make a profit out of a disturbance or difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: आपदा में अवसर ढूंढना / बहती गंगा में हाथ धोना।

content.usage: He is accused of fishing in troubled waters during the political crisis.

extras.mnemonic: Fish come to the surface when water is agitated, making them easier to catch.

meanings.english: To attempt to do the impossible; waste energy on a futile effort.
meanings.hindi: मुर्दे में जान डालने की कोशिश करना / व्यर्थ प्रयास करना।

content.usage: Discussing this issue again is just flogging a dead horse.

extras.mnemonic: Whipping (flogging) a dead horse won't make it move.

meanings.english: To be enraged; to get very angry.
meanings.hindi: गुस्से से पागल होना / मुंह से झाग निकालना।

content.usage: The customer was foaming at the mouth about the poor service.

extras.mnemonic: Rabid dogs foam at the mouth; implies mad anger.
extras.origin: Medical symptom of rabies associated with madness.

meanings.english: To make progress; become more popular.

content.usage: The anti-smoking campaign is gaining ground.

extras.mnemonic: An army capturing territory (ground) from the enemy.

meanings.english: To seek all enjoyments of life.

content.usage: Life is not just about gathering roses only; you must face thorns too.

extras.mnemonic: Picking the flowers but avoiding the thorns.

meanings.english: To escape punishment for a wrong deed.

content.usage: He robbed the bank and got away with it.

extras.mnemonic: Moving away with the stolen goods/act unstopped.

meanings.english: To experience nervousness; lose confidence.

content.usage: He got cold feet right before the wedding.

extras.mnemonic: Blood leaves the extremities (feet) when you are frightened.

meanings.english: To get into trouble.

content.usage: He got into hot water with his boss for being late.

extras.mnemonic: Being boiled in hot water is painful.
extras.origin: 16th century: to be in trouble like an intruder poured with boiling water.

content.phrase: To get more kicks than halfpence

meanings.english: Harsh treatment rather than rewards; more trouble than profit.
meanings.hindi: लाभ से अधिक हानि / अपमान सहना।

content.usage: Working for that miser, I get more kicks than halfpence.

extras.mnemonic: Like a performing monkey that gets kicked more often than it gets coins.
extras.origin: Refers to the life of performing animals.

meanings.english: To get revenge.

content.usage: He played a prank on me, but I'll get my own back soon.

extras.mnemonic: Recovering what was taken from you (getting it back).

meanings.english: To prepare for hard work or a difficult situation.

content.usage: The team girded up their loins for the final match.

extras.mnemonic: In ancient times, men tied up their long robes (loins) to move freely for battle.

content.phrase: To give the devil his due

meanings.english: To give credit to a bad person for their good qualities.
meanings.hindi: बुरे व्यक्ति की भी अच्छाई को मानना।

content.usage: I dislike him, but to give the devil his due, he is a brilliant planner.

extras.mnemonic: Even the Devil has some skills worth acknowledging.

meanings.english: To escape from someone; dodge.

content.usage: The thief managed to give the police the slip in the crowded market.

extras.mnemonic: Slipping away from someone's grip.

meanings.english: Get very angry, irrational, or excited.
meanings.hindi: पागल हो जाना / बहुत गुस्सा या खुश होना।

content.usage: My dad went bananas when I dented the car.

extras.mnemonic: Monkeys go crazy for bananas.

meanings.english: Become crazy; go insane; get very angry.
meanings.hindi: दिमाग फिर जाना / पागल हो जाना।

content.usage: He will go nuts if he finds out you broke his phone.

extras.mnemonic: Nut = head; going nuts implies losing your head.

meanings.english: To stop broadcasting a TV or Radio programme.

content.usage: The popular show went off the air last year.

extras.mnemonic: No longer transmitting through the airwaves.

content.phrase: To go red in the face

meanings.english: Feel embarrassed.

content.usage: She went red in the face when she tripped on the stage.

extras.mnemonic: Blushing causes redness due to blood rushing to the face.

meanings.english: To waste time and energy without making progress.
meanings.hindi: गोल-गोल घूमना / कोई नतीजा न निकलना।

content.usage: We are just going round in circles with this discussion.

extras.mnemonic: Walking in a circle brings you back to the start.
extras.origin: Visual metaphor for lack of progress.

meanings.english: To escape without punishment.
meanings.hindi: साफ बच निकलना / बिना सजा के।

content.usage: The real culprit went scot free due to lack of evidence.

extras.mnemonic: 'Skat' was an old Scandinavian tax; going 'scot free' meant not paying the tax.

meanings.english: To do something as completely as possible.
meanings.hindi: पूरा जोर लगाना / अंत तक जाना।

content.usage: If we are going to renovate, let's go the whole hog and repaint everything.

extras.mnemonic: Buying the whole pig (hog) instead of just a part.
extras.origin: Butcher slang or possibly a shilling coin called a 'hog'.

meanings.english: To make someone arrogant (success) or dizzy (alcohol).
meanings.hindi: सिर पर चढ़ना / घमंड हो जाना।

content.usage: Don't let the fame go to your head.

extras.mnemonic: Fumes rising to the head causing dizziness/confusion.

meanings.english: To fail completely; fall into a bad state.
meanings.hindi: बर्बाद हो जाना / रसातल में जाना।

content.usage: Since he started drinking, his business has gone to the devil.

extras.mnemonic: Heading towards hell/ruin.

meanings.english: To come from (birthplace or residence).

content.usage: He hails from a small village in Punjab.

extras.mnemonic: Hailing a ship to ask where it comes from.

meanings.english: To arrive at an agreement through discussion.

content.usage: The two sides managed to hammer out a peace treaty.

extras.mnemonic: Blacksmith hammering metal into the desired shape.

meanings.english: To be connected; to support one another.

content.usage: We must hang together or we will fail separately.

extras.mnemonic: Benjamin Franklin: 'We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang separately.'

meanings.english: To have a very good time.

content.usage: We had a blast at the party last night.

extras.mnemonic: An explosion (blast) of fun.

meanings.english: To feel an intuition or strong instinct.

content.usage: I have a gut feeling that something is wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Feeling it in your stomach (gut) rather than brain.

meanings.english: To have knowledge readily available.
meanings.hindi: पूरी जानकारी होना / जुबानी याद होना।

content.usage: She has all the statistics at her fingertips.

extras.mnemonic: So close you can touch it with your fingers.

meanings.english: To look upon something with prejudice or dislike.

content.usage: He views all government actions with a jaundiced eye.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Jaundiced eye' (ID 432).

meanings.english: Know something or someone slightly.

content.usage: I have only a nodding acquaintance with German.

extras.mnemonic: You only nod at them when you pass; you don't stop to talk.

content.phrase: Bitten off more than you can chew

meanings.english: Take on a responsibility too big to handle.
meanings.hindi: औकात से ज्यादा काम ले लेना।

content.usage: He bit off more than he could chew by accepting three projects at once.

extras.mnemonic: Taking a bite of food too big to swallow.

meanings.english: Have a strong desire or craving for something.

content.usage: I have a yen for Chinese food tonight.

extras.mnemonic: Yen comes from Chinese 'yan' meaning craving (often for opium).

content.phrase: To have egg on one's face

meanings.english: To be embarrassed due to one's action.

content.usage: He had egg on his face after his predictions turned out wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Having food messy on your face is embarrassing.
extras.origin: Theatre crowds throwing eggs at bad actors.

meanings.english: To reconsider a decision.

content.usage: I'm having second thoughts about buying this expensive car.

extras.mnemonic: Thinking about it a second time implies doubt.

content.phrase: To have something on the brain

meanings.english: To be obsessed with something; thinking about it constantly.

content.usage: He has football on the brain; he talks about nothing else.

extras.mnemonic: It's stuck on your brain physically.

content.phrase: To have something up one's sleeve

meanings.english: To have a secret or alternative plan.
meanings.hindi: गुप्त योजना होना / इक्का छिपा कर रखना।

content.usage: I think he has a trick up his sleeve.

extras.mnemonic: Magicians hide cards up their sleeves.

meanings.english: As much as he wanted to.

content.usage: The children played in the park to their heart's content.

extras.mnemonic: Until the heart is satisfied (content).

meanings.english: To attack in an unfair way.
meanings.hindi: धोखे से वार करना / गलत तरीके से हमला करना।

content.usage: Bringing up his divorce was hitting below the belt.

extras.mnemonic: In boxing, hitting below the waist is illegal.

meanings.english: To be successful or accurate.

content.usage: His speech really hit the mark with the audience.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting the target.

meanings.english: To gain sudden success or wealth.

content.usage: He hit the jackpot with his new invention.

extras.mnemonic: Winning the top prize in a slot machine.

meanings.english: Begin one's journey.

content.usage: It's getting late; we should hit the road.

extras.mnemonic: Your feet/tires hitting the pavement.

meanings.english: To go to bed.

content.usage: I'm tired, I'm going to hit the sack.

extras.mnemonic: Mattresses used to be sacks filled with hay.

meanings.english: To advocate for someone; to support or defend.

content.usage: I hold no brief for his actions, but I understand why he did it.

extras.mnemonic: A lawyer holds a 'brief' (case file) to defend a client.

meanings.english: To remain valid.

content.usage: This rule holds good for everyone.

extras.mnemonic: Holding its value/truth.

meanings.english: To breathe heavily from exertion; to complain loudly.

content.usage: He huffed and puffed up the stairs.

extras.mnemonic: The Big Bad Wolf huffed and puffed to blow the house down.

meanings.english: To follow popular trends; join a winning side.
meanings.hindi: बहती गंगा में हाथ धोना / भेड़चाल चलना।

content.usage: Many companies jumped on the green energy bandwagon.

extras.mnemonic: Politicians used bandwagons (wagons with bands) for campaigns; people jumped on to show support.

content.phrase: To jump out of one's skin

meanings.english: To be extremely surprised or frightened.

content.usage: The loud bang made me jump out of my skin.

extras.mnemonic: Jumping so hard you leave your body behind.

meanings.english: To provide luxurious food; entertain guests well.

content.usage: She is a wonderful hostess and keeps a good table.

extras.mnemonic: The dining table is always full of good things.

meanings.english: To watch carefully; monitor.

content.usage: Please keep an eye on my bag while I buy a ticket.

extras.mnemonic: Fixing your vision (eye) on something.

content.phrase: To keep body and soul together

meanings.english: To have just enough to survive.

content.usage: He earns barely enough to keep body and soul together.

extras.mnemonic: Keeping the soul inside the body (staying alive).

meanings.english: To suspend temporarily.
meanings.hindi: ठंडे बस्ते में डालना / स्थगित रखना।

content.usage: The project was kept in abeyance due to lack of funds.

extras.mnemonic: Abeyance means temporary suspension (legal term).

meanings.english: To remain calm; not get angry.

content.usage: It was hard to keep my temper when he insulted me.

extras.mnemonic: Holding onto your temper instead of losing it.

content.phrase: To keep the wolf from the door

meanings.english: To have enough money to avoid starvation.

content.usage: He took a second job to keep the wolf from the door.

extras.mnemonic: The wolf represents hunger/famine waiting outside.

content.phrase: To keep someone at arm's length

meanings.english: To avoid being friendly or close to someone.

content.usage: She keeps her colleagues at arm's length.

extras.mnemonic: Holding someone away so they can't get closer than your arm.

meanings.english: To maintain progress.

content.usage: I've started the discussion; now you keep the ball rolling.

extras.mnemonic: A rolling ball continues moving with momentum.

meanings.english: To keep secret.

content.usage: The new car model is being kept under wraps until the launch.

extras.mnemonic: Wrapped up so no one can see it.

meanings.english: To continue; maintain pace.

content.usage: Keep up the good work!

extras.mnemonic: Holding something up so it doesn't fall/stop.

meanings.english: To know the facts; have common sense.

content.usage: He's been in the business for years; he knows what's what.

extras.mnemonic: Knowing the definition/value of things.

meanings.english: To fail to maintain pace; fall behind.

content.usage: Our sales are lagging behind our competitors.

extras.mnemonic: Lag implies delay/slowness.

meanings.english: To be hired successfully.

content.usage: She managed to land a job at Google.

extras.mnemonic: Fishing metaphor: landing a fish (catching it).

meanings.english: To arrest; imprison; render powerless.

content.usage: The police finally laid the gang leader by the heels.

extras.mnemonic: Putting someone in leg irons/stocks holds their heels.

meanings.english: To misguide; take away from the correct path.

content.usage: Bad friends led him astray.

extras.mnemonic: A stray animal is lost; leading someone to become a stray.

meanings.english: To not punish or punish lightly.

content.usage: The judge let him off with a warning.

extras.mnemonic: Letting someone off the hook.

meanings.english: To look disheartened or depressed.

content.usage: Why do you look so blue today?

extras.mnemonic: Blue color represents sadness.

meanings.english: To regard with contempt; consider inferior.
meanings.hindi: तुच्छ समझना / हेय दृष्टि से देखना।

content.usage: She looks down her nose at anyone who buys cheap clothes.

extras.mnemonic: Tilting head back to look down implies arrogance.

meanings.english: Become less popular or successful.

content.usage: The ruling party is losing ground in the polls.

extras.mnemonic: An army retreating loses the ground it held.

meanings.english: To become very angry.

content.usage: He lost his temper and shouted at the waiter.

extras.mnemonic: Losing control of your mood.

meanings.english: To cause needless commotion or complaint.

content.usage: Stop making a fuss about the food.

extras.mnemonic: Fuss implies unnecessary activity/worry.

content.phrase: To make a mountain of a molehill

meanings.english: Exaggerate a minor problem.

content.usage: It's a small scratch; don't make a mountain of a molehill.

extras.mnemonic: A molehill is tiny; a mountain is huge.

meanings.english: To make a lot of money.

content.usage: He made a pile in the stock market.

extras.mnemonic: A pile of gold/money.

meanings.english: To correct a mistake; compensate.

content.usage: He bought her flowers to make amends for being late.

extras.mnemonic: Amending (fixing) a wrong.

meanings.english: To live within one's income; survive financially.

content.usage: With rising prices, it's hard to make both ends meet.

extras.mnemonic: Making the income end meet the expense end.

meanings.english: To manage with whatever is available.

content.usage: We didn't have a hammer, so we made do with a rock.

extras.mnemonic: Making something 'do' the job even if it's not perfect.

meanings.english: To enjoy oneself; have fun.

content.usage: The villagers made merry at the festival.

extras.mnemonic: Eat, drink, and be merry.

meanings.english: To make someone very angry.

content.usage: His arrogant attitude makes my blood boil.

extras.mnemonic: Anger feels like heat inside.

meanings.english: To decide.

content.usage: I have made up my mind to resign.

extras.mnemonic: Assembling your thoughts into a decision.

meanings.english: To engage in competition; fight.

content.usage: The two champions will measure swords in the finals.

extras.mnemonic: Before a duel, swords were measured to ensure equal length/fairness.

content.phrase: To mind one's P's and Q's

meanings.english: To be careful about one's speech and behavior.
meanings.hindi: शिष्टाचार का ध्यान रखना / सावधानी बरतना।

content.usage: You must mind your P's and Q's when visiting the Queen.

extras.mnemonic: Typesetters had to be careful not to confuse 'p' and 'q'; or bartenders watching 'pints' and 'quarts'.

meanings.english: To miss an opportunity.

content.usage: He missed the boat by not investing in Bitcoin early.

extras.mnemonic: If you are late, the boat leaves without you.

meanings.english: To stop something at an early stage.
meanings.hindi: पनपने से पहले ही नष्ट कर देना।

content.usage: We must nip this bad habit in the bud.

extras.mnemonic: Destroying a flower bud prevents it from growing.

meanings.english: To not know anything about something.

content.usage: I don't have a clue how to fix this machine.

extras.mnemonic: Without a clue (hint), the puzzle is unsolvable.

content.phrase: Cut one's coat according to one's cloth

meanings.english: Live within one's means.
meanings.hindi: तेते पाँव पसारिये जेती लांबी सौर / औकात में रहना।

content.usage: We can't afford a luxury car; we must cut our coat according to our cloth.

extras.mnemonic: You can't make a big coat if you only have a small cloth.

meanings.english: To be independent and self-reliant.
meanings.hindi: आत्मनिर्भर होना / अपनी जिम्मेदारी खुद उठाना।

content.usage: He left home at 18 to paddle his own canoe.

extras.mnemonic: In a canoe, you must row yourself.

meanings.english: To encounter ultimate defeat.
meanings.hindi: करारी हार होना / अंत आ जाना।

content.usage: The undefeated champion finally met his Waterloo.

extras.mnemonic: Napoleon was finally defeated at the Battle of Waterloo (1815).

meanings.english: To take revenge.
meanings.hindi: पुराना हिसाब चुकता करना / बदला लेना।

content.usage: He used his power to pay off old scores with his enemies.

extras.mnemonic: Settling the score (debt) of insults.

meanings.english: Pay an extremely high price.
meanings.hindi: मुंहमांगी कीमत देना / बहुत ज्यादा पैसा खर्चना।

content.usage: We paid through the nose for those concert tickets.

extras.mnemonic: Possible link to 'nose tax' in Ireland or bleeding money.
extras.origin: 9th-century Danish poll tax in Ireland (slit nose if unpaid).

meanings.english: To criticize someone; find faults.

content.usage: It's easy to pick holes in someone else's work.

extras.mnemonic: Finding tiny holes in fabric to reject it.

meanings.english: To restart from the previous closing point.
meanings.hindi: सिलसिला वहीं से जोड़ना जहाँ टूटा था।

content.usage: After the break, we picked up the threads of our conversation.

extras.mnemonic: Ideally weaving or sewing where you left off.

meanings.english: To categorize unfairly; put aside.
meanings.hindi: खांचे में बांटना / ठंडे बस्ते में डालना।

content.usage: Don't pigeonhole me as just a comedian; I can act drama too.

extras.mnemonic: Pigeonholes are small compartments in a desk for sorting mail.

meanings.english: Behave irresponsibly or immorally.

content.usage: You can't play fast and loose with people's feelings.

extras.mnemonic: From a cheating fairground game 'Fast and Loose'.

meanings.english: To be in a subordinate role.
meanings.hindi: दोयम दर्जे का होना / सहायक भूमिका निभाना।

content.usage: He tired of playing second fiddle to his partner.

extras.mnemonic: In an orchestra, the first fiddle leads; the second supports.

meanings.english: To propose marriage.

content.usage: He plans to pop the question on Valentine's Day.

extras.mnemonic: Popping out the most important question.

meanings.english: Encourage the growth or action of something (usually financially).

content.usage: The government cut taxes to prime the pump of the economy.

extras.mnemonic: You pour water into an old pump to get it started.

meanings.english: To behave in a way intended to make people admire you; cheap popularity.
meanings.hindi: जनता को खुश करना / दिखावा करना।

content.usage: His speeches are just playing to the gallery.

extras.mnemonic: Acting for the cheap seats (gallery) rather than the critics.

content.phrase: To pour oil on troubled waters

meanings.english: To calm a dispute.

content.usage: The mother poured oil on troubled waters when the siblings fought.

extras.mnemonic: Oil floats on water and smooths the waves.

meanings.english: To cheat or deceive someone.

content.usage: Don't let him pull a fast one on you with that contract.

extras.mnemonic: Moving too fast to be seen (sleight of hand).

meanings.english: To make fun of someone; tease.

content.usage: I was just pulling your leg; I didn't really win the lottery.

extras.mnemonic: Tripping someone up metaphorically.

content.phrase: To put a spoke in one's wheel

meanings.english: To hinder; thwart plans.

content.usage: His refusal put a spoke in our wheel.

extras.mnemonic: Jamming a stick (spoke) into a spinning wheel stops it.

meanings.english: To make ashamed or disconcerted.

content.usage: Her stare put him out of countenance.

extras.mnemonic: Countenance = face/composure; losing it means looking ashamed.

meanings.english: Stop; abolish.

content.usage: The new law will put an end to this practice.

extras.mnemonic: Placing an 'End' sign on something.

content.phrase: To put one's foot in one's mouth

meanings.english: To accidentally embarrass or upset someone; say something stupid.
meanings.hindi: मुंह से गलत बात निकल जाना / शर्मिंदा होना।

content.usage: I really put my foot in my mouth by asking about her ex-husband.

extras.mnemonic: Ideally, only food goes in the mouth; putting a foot in is clumsy and blocks speech.

content.phrase: To put someone to the sword

meanings.english: To slay or execute someone.

content.usage: The invaders put the entire village to the sword.

extras.mnemonic: Applying the sword to the person.

content.phrase: To put one's hand to the plough

meanings.english: Get busy working; start a difficult task.

content.usage: Once you put your hand to the plough, you shouldn't look back.

extras.mnemonic: Ploughing a field requires holding the plough firmly and moving forward.

meanings.english: To postpone something.

content.usage: We have to put the party on hold until he recovers.

extras.mnemonic: Holding a phone call; waiting.

meanings.english: Tolerate; endure.

content.usage: I can't put up with his rude behavior anymore.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb.

meanings.english: To stop helping someone especially when support is needed.

content.usage: Don't quit on me now; we're almost finished.

extras.mnemonic: Quitting the job of being a friend/helper.

meanings.english: To cause disruption or confusion.

content.usage: His comments raised a dust in the media.

extras.mnemonic: Running/fighting kicks up dust, blinding others.

meanings.english: To obtain necessary funds.

content.usage: He pawned his watch to raise the wind for rent.

extras.mnemonic: Sailors whistling to 'raise the wind' for sailing; needing resources to move.

content.phrase: To roll out the red carpet

meanings.english: To give a grand welcome.

content.usage: They rolled out the red carpet for the visiting President.

extras.mnemonic: Red carpets are laid for royalty/VIPs.

content.phrase: To rub salt in someone's wound

meanings.english: To make a bad situation worse; aggravate pain.

content.usage: Laughing at his failure was just rubbing salt in his wound.

extras.mnemonic: Salt stings painfully on raw flesh.

meanings.english: To meet someone by chance.

content.usage: I ran across an old diary while cleaning.

extras.mnemonic: Crossing paths while running/walking.

meanings.english: To behave uncontrollably and disruptively; go mad.

content.usage: The crowd ran amok after the concert was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: From Malay 'amuk' meaning attacking furiously.

content.phrase: To run around like a headless chicken

meanings.english: To do many things in a disorganized manner.
meanings.hindi: बदहवास होकर दौड़ना / बिना दिशा के भागना।

content.usage: Calm down; stop running around like a headless chicken.

extras.mnemonic: A chicken continues to run aimlessly for seconds after being beheaded.

meanings.english: To disparage someone; criticize unfairly.

content.usage: He is always running his brother down out of jealousy.

extras.mnemonic: Running over someone (figuratively crushing them).

meanings.english: To increase in size, number, or importance.

content.usage: The company plans to scale up production next year.

extras.mnemonic: Climbing up the scale (ladder/graph).

meanings.english: To put something extra aside; save; annul.
meanings.hindi: बचत करना / रद्द करना / अलग रखना।

content.usage: The court set aside the verdict. / He sets aside money for holidays.

extras.mnemonic: Putting it to the side for later or discarding.

content.phrase: To set the Thames on fire

meanings.english: Do a heroic or wonderful deed (often used negatively: he won't set the Thames on fire).
meanings.hindi: अनोखा काम करना / दुनिया हिला देना।

content.usage: He's a nice boy, but he'll never set the Thames on fire.

extras.mnemonic: It's impossible to burn a river; doing so would be a miracle.

meanings.english: To be afraid.

content.usage: The bully made the little boy shake in his shoes.

extras.mnemonic: Trembling so hard your shoes vibrate.

meanings.english: False tears; pretending to be sad.

content.usage: She shed crocodile tears at the funeral of her rich uncle.

extras.mnemonic: Crocodiles were believed to weep while eating their prey to lure victims.

content.phrase: To show a clean pair of heels

meanings.english: Run away; escape.
meanings.hindi: नौ दो ग्यारह होना / भाग जाना।

content.usage: The thief showed a clean pair of heels as soon as the police arrived.

extras.mnemonic: When running away fast, you lift your heels high so they are visible.

meanings.english: To take action that causes future trouble or conflict.

content.usage: The harsh treaty sowed dragon's teeth for the next war.

extras.mnemonic: In myth, Cadmus sowed dragon teeth which turned into armed soldiers who fought each other.

content.phrase: To sit at the feet of someone

meanings.english: To be a disciple or student of someone.

content.usage: He sat at the feet of the great musician to learn the art.

extras.mnemonic: Students traditionally sat on the floor while the master sat on a chair.

meanings.english: To sleep soundly.
meanings.hindi: घोड़े बेचकर सोना / गहरी नींद सोना।

content.usage: After the hike, I slept like a dog.

extras.mnemonic: Dogs sleep deeply and comfortably.
extras.origin: Usually 'sleep like a log' or 'sleep like a dog' (idiomatic variation).

meanings.english: To avoid deliberately; keep away from.

content.usage: She shuns publicity and lives a quiet life.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like 'shun' (to push away).

meanings.english: Suspect a trick or deceit.
meanings.hindi: दाल में काला लगना / शक होना।

content.usage: When he offered me the car for $50, I smelt a rat.

extras.mnemonic: A cat smells a rat hidden nearby; sensing something hidden and bad.

meanings.english: Raise an alarm; warn of danger.
meanings.hindi: खतरे की घंटी बजाना / चेतावनी देना।

content.usage: The scientists sounded a red alert about the melting glaciers.

extras.mnemonic: Red is the color of danger.

meanings.english: To express one's thoughts frankly.
meanings.hindi: मन की बात कहना / स्पष्ट बोलना।

content.usage: He is never afraid to speak his mind.

extras.mnemonic: Letting out what is in the mind.

content.phrase: To stand on one's own feet

meanings.english: To be strong and independent.
meanings.hindi: अपने पैरों पर खड़ा होना / आत्मनिर्भर होना।

content.usage: It's time you got a job and stood on your own feet.

extras.mnemonic: Supporting your own weight without crutches or help.

meanings.english: Postpone; ward off.

content.usage: He ate a snack to stave off hunger.

extras.mnemonic: Using a staff (stave) to push something away.

meanings.english: Gain an advantage unexpectedly or secretly.
meanings.hindi: चुपके से आगे निकल जाना / बाजी मार लेना।

content.usage: Our company stole a march on competitors by launching the product early.

extras.mnemonic: Moving troops at night (stealing a march) to get ahead of the enemy.

meanings.english: Take credit or attention away from someone else.
meanings.hindi: श्रेय ले लेना / किसी का प्रभाव कम करना।

content.usage: See ID 744.

extras.mnemonic: See ID 744.

meanings.english: Avoid.

content.usage: I try to steer clear of trouble.

extras.mnemonic: Steering a ship away from rocks/danger.

meanings.english: Relax; calm down.

content.usage: Stop shouting and take a chill pill.
